Where desirable to plat wedge-shaped lots so as to best utilize a parcel of land, the required lot width shall be measured at the front building line and parallel to the front property line, and when the front building line is narrower than the front lot line, the lot width shall be measured at the rear building line and be parallel to the rear property line. 
(d)  Depth. The depth of a lot should not exceed a depth to width ratio of 2½ to one. 
(e)  Corner lots. Corner lots shall be provided extra width sufficient to permit the maintenance of building setback lines on both the front and side street lines in order to protect similar setbacks on both the front and side streets which exist or are planned. Where lots have side yards abutting upon a street, on the same side of which other residential lots front, the lots shall be of such width as to permit a side yard setback on the street equivalent to the required front yard setback of the lots fronting on such street. 
(f)  Side lot lines. Side property lines of lots shall generally be perpendicular to straight street lines on radial to curved street lines unless the Planning Commission determines that a variation from such requirement will afford a better lot layout. Property lines on sides and rear of lots should be straight. 
(g)  Depth and area. The depth and area of lots will be in conformance with the minimum lot areas specified in chapter 38, zoning. 
(h)  Business or commercial lots. No lot or parcel classified as business or commercial shall be platted that is less than 50 feet in width. The area of such lot or parcel shall be sufficient in overall size so as to provide sufficient area for the off-street parking and loading requirements of chapter 38, zoning. 
(i)  Building lines and setback lines. Building and setback lines shall conform to the requirements of chapter 38, zoning. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 403, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-136. - Blocks. 
(a)  Generally. The size and shape of blocks shall be appropriate for the type of lots and land use proposed. Blocks shall be designed so as to permit good lot orientation, safe street design and economical use of the land. 
(b)  Length. The length of blocks between intersecting streets shall normally be within the range of 800 to 1,000 feet. Such form shall be altered only where, in the opinion of the Township Planning Commission, the topography of the land makes it advisable to do so in order to protect the public safety and convenience, and in no event shall blocks be less than 500 feet or more than 1,320 feet in length. 
(c)  Arrangement. A block should be designed so as to provide two tiers of lots, except where lots back onto a major street, natural feature or subdivision boundary. 
(d)  Nonresidential blocks. Blocks intended for purposes other than residential shall be especially designed for such purposes and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking, access and loading in accordance with the applicable requirements of chapter 38, zoning. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 404, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-137. - Uses, restrictions and modifications. 
(a)  Control. The subdivision of property for residential or similar uses shall not be permitted where, in the opinion of the Planning Commission, the area involved is unsuitable for building purposes, such as, in the case of prohibitive topography, very poor soil characteristics or conservative objectives. In any event, all uses and property configurations are subject to the applicable provisions of chapter 38, zoning. 
(b)  Commercial or industrial modifications. The subdivision design standards of this division may be modified in accordance with division 5 of this article in the case of a subdivision specifically for commercial or individual development, including shopping districts, wholesaling areas and planned industrial districts. In all cases, however, adequate provision shall be made for off-street parking, access and loading areas, as well as traffic circulation provisions. 
(c)  Flooding. Any areas within the proposed plat which are subject to flooding, inundation by stormwater or within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or have inadequate drainage, shall not be platted for any use so as to increase danger to life, health or property. If the Township Board determines that a flood problem does exist, then the Township Board shall reject all or part of the proposed plat laying within the floodplain, and shall require compliance with the land division act and review by the state department of environmental quality. The proprietor may show, by engineering site plans, that a change in the topography will eliminate flooding and shall demonstrate that any planned topographical change will not aggravate the flood hazard beyond the limits of the plat. 
(d)  Open spaces. In the design of the plat, thorough and equitable consideration shall be given by the subdivider and the Planning Commission to the provision of suitable sites for recreational, school and other public purposes. When a proposed park, playground, school or other public use shown on the comprehensive development plan is located, in whole or in part, within a subdivision, a suitable area for such purpose may be dedicated to the public purchase. If, within two years of plat recording, the purchase is not agreed on, the reservation may be cancelled or shall automatically cease to exist. 
(e)  Protection of natural features. Due regard shall be shown for all natural features, such as large trees, exceptionally fine groves of trees, watercourses, scenic points, historic spots and similar community assets, which, when preserved, will add a certain attractiveness and value to the subdivision. 
(f)  Woodlands protection and preservation. 
(1)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this subsection to protect woodlands within the Township and preserve the economic, health, aesthetic and environmental values associated with woodlands. Regulation of the removal of tree resources will help protect and preserve an important natural feature of the Township for the benefit of present and future generations, and for the future well-being of the public health, the Township's character and the natural environment. The provisions of this subsection are also intended to prohibit clearcutting of woodland areas within the Township. 
(2)  Regulated activities. This subsection shall apply to land for which a site plan, plat or site condominium plan has been submitted for approval to the Planning Commission on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection is derived. The provisions of this subsection shall also apply to simple land divisions under the land division provisions in article II of this chapter and the state land division act. 
(3)  Exemptions. The following activities or conditions are permitted under this subsection unless otherwise prohibited by statute or other ordinances: 
a.  Residential parcels of five acres or less. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, removal or transplantation of trees is permitted on residential parcels of five acres or less, provided, the parcel supports only one dwelling and permitted residential accessory uses, and, provided that the parcel is not part of a site plan, plat or site condominium being reviewed or anticipated for review under subsection (f)(2) of this section. Such exemption shall not apply to landmark trees located on such parcels. 
b.  Emergencies. This subsection shall not bar tree removal, transplantation or other prohibited activities where such actions were made necessary by a genuine emergency, such as a tornado, windstorm, flood, freeze, dangerous and infectious insect infestation or disease, or other natural or manmade disasters, in order to prevent injury or damage to persons or property, or to restore order. 
c.  Dead or damaged trees. This subsection shall not bar removal, transplantation or trimming of dead, diseased, infested or damaged trees, where the damage resulted from an accident or natural cause, and, provided that the removal or trimming is accomplished through the use of accepted standard forestry practices and techniques. 
d.  Public utilities. This subsection shall not bar the repair or maintenance work performed by public utilities which would necessarily require the trimming or cutting of trees. However, it is intended to encourage the preservation of trees by public utilities, wherever possible. 
e.  Agricultural uses. This subsection shall not bar removal or transplantation of trees occurring during the use of the land for agriculture, or the operation of a commercial nursery or certified tree farm, provided, the commercial nursery or certified tree farm has been licensed with the state and has received all other necessary licenses and permits. 
f.  Woodlands management. Thinning, selective clearing and trimming of trees shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this subsection, if such work is conducted in accordance with professional forest management and registered in the state. Woodlands management activities shall not, however, include clearcutting or the wholesale removal of significant vegetation from the site. 
(4)  Tree inventory. 
a.  For all lands, parcels and projects to which this subsection applies, a tree inventory shall be required. The Planning Commission shall have the authority to waive the tree inventory requirements of this subsection (4), if it is determined to be unreasonable, unnecessary or not applicable, provided, the Planning Commission shall not have the authority to waive the tree inventory requirements for woodlands within building envelopes and when pertaining to landmark trees. If the tree inventory is waived, the Planning Commission may still require compliance with some of the noted required information, and may also include an indication of tree massing and a statement indicating predominate species and the estimated number and size of trees on the site within each massing. 
b.  The tree inventory shall include the following information: 
1.  An inventory indicating the location of all existing trees that are six inches or more in diameter at breast height (dbh), including off-site trees within 25 feet of the property lines, and all trees to be affected by the development, such as trees located within areas of right-of-way improvements or off-site utility work. All such trees proposed to remain, be relocated or be removed shall be so designated. Clearing limits shall be clearly shown on the inventory. The inventory shall be accompanied by a separate key, identifying the numbered trees by size, common name and condition. 
2.  Tree location inventories are to be performed by an actual field survey by a registered land surveyor, registered landscape architect, or certified arborist or forester. Professionals must verify the contents by seal or signature, whichever is applicable. 
3.  If existing trees are to be relocated, the proposed location for such trees shall be shown, together with a statement as to how such trees are to be protected and/or stored during land clearance and construction, and how they are to be maintained after construction. 
4.  A statement showing how trees to remain are to be protected during land clearance, construction and on a permanent basis, including the proposed use of tree wells, protective barriers, tunneling or retaining walls. 
5.  A description of the soil types and characteristics. 
(5)  Historic or landmark trees. 
a.  A nomination for historic or landmark tree designation shall be reviewed and determined by the Planning Commission. 
b.  Any Township property owner may nominate a tree within their own property boundaries for designation as a landmark tree or historic tree. If nominated, the Planning Commission shall review the nomination request and, if the tree is determined to meet the criteria listed in subsection (5)c of this section, such tree shall be placed on the Township's landmark tree inventory. 
c.  The Planning Commission may designate a tree, upon nomination, as an historic tree upon a finding that one or more of the following unique characteristics exist: 
1.  The tree is the predominant tree within a distinct scenic or aesthetically valued setting. 
2.  The tree is of unusual age or size for that species in this climatic and geographic location. (Examples include trees listed on the register of big trees or the state botanical club as large trees). 
3.  The tree has gained prominence due to unusual form or botanical characteristics. 
4.  The tree has some historical significance to the Township. 
d.  The building department shall maintain an inventory of all nominated and designated historic landmark trees. 
e.  A permit shall be required to remove any landmark or historic tree. Any historic tree shall be replaced on a one to one caliper inch basis. For example, a 48-inch landmark tree shall be replaced by 24 two-inch trees. Such replacement requirement may be waived if, in the opinion of the Planning Commission and after review by the Township's consultants, the health or condition of the tree is such that it should not be counted. 
(6)  Landmark trees. All landmark trees as identified in section 38-363(f) shall be designated. 
(7)  Tree removal and protection. Developments that are subject to the woodland preservation regulations set forth in this subsection shall indicate all trees proposed to be removed and those to be preserved on the provided tree inventory. The trees designated for protection shall be properly protected from damage due to construction operations and development. Prior to commencement of development or construction operations, land clearing, filling or any land alteration, a developer must erect and maintain suitable protective barriers to protect trees designated to remain under the submitted plan. The protective barriers shall be required for all trees designated to remain in place by the submitted plan. 
(8)  Development of land parcels. Subject to the exemptions listed in subsection (3) of this section, no person shall remove, cause to be removed, transplant or destroy, on any land in the Township slated for land development to which this article applies, any tree having a six-inch or greater dbh, without first obtaining approval subject to the provisions of this subsection. 
(9)  Tree mitigation and replacement. 
a.  Requirements established. For each protected tree required to be preserved under the terms and standards set forth in this subsection, and which is permitted to be removed under this subsection, the applicant shall replace or relocate trees according to the replacement tree requirements set forth in subsection (9)b of this section. 
b.  Replacement tree requirements. 
1.  Replacement trees shall have shade potential and/or other characteristics comparable to the removed trees, shall be state department of agriculture nursery grade No. 1 or better, and must be approved by the Township prior to planting. Replacement trees must be staked, fertilized, mulched and watered, and shall be guaranteed by the applicant for two years. 
2.  Trees usable for replacement trees may be transplanted on-site, using appropriate and accepted procedures and precautions. 
3.  For all regulated trees removed, replacement shall be on a one for one basis. For example, for each tree removed, a replacement tree shall be planted. All replacement trees shall have a dbh of at least two inches. All evergreen replacement trees shall be at least six feet tall. 
4.  Landmark trees shall be replaced at a rate of one inch of replacement tree for each dbh inch of landmark tree removed. 
5.  If more than 50 percent of the parcel of land is designated on the Township's woodland map, an applicant shall not be required to replace more than 30 percent of all protected trees, excluding landmark trees. 
6.  The Planning Commission shall be authorized to waive portions of the tree replacement requirements of this subsection (9)b when site factors, tree conditions or development requirements warrant special consideration, or if the applicant has adjusted the site design to save landmark trees. 
c.  Replacement tree relocation. 
1.  The Township shall approve tree relocation or replacement at off-site locations in order to provide optimum enhancement, preservation and protection of wooded areas. To the extent feasible and desirable, trees shall be relocated or replaced on-site and within the same general area as trees removed, provided that survival shall not be jeopardized by improvements or activities. 
2.  Where it is not feasible and desirable to relocate or replace trees on site, relocation or replacement may be made at another location in the Township that is approved as part of the approval. 
d.  Environmental trust fund. If lot coverage or site characteristics prohibit on-site or off-site mitigation, contribution to the Township's environmental trust fund may be permitted. In lieu of replacing regulated trees, the Planning Commission may direct the applicant to exercise the option to contribute money to the Township's Environmental Trust Fund. Payment to such fund per tree removed shall be in accordance with replacement fee schedules as established by the Township Board, and shall be used to fund tree planting activities on public land or public right-of-way areas. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 405, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 104, § 1, 1-3-2001)  
Sec. 18-138. - Required improvements. 
In order to provide healthful, clean and desirable living conditions, the subdivider shall be entirely responsible for installing the following site improvements, or shall furnish a cash deposit or its equivalent acceptable to the Township Board, sufficient to permit the completion of all contemplated improvements, before a plat shall be accepted by the Township: 
(1)  Street pavement. Street improvements shall be provided by the proprietor in accordance with the standards and specifications of the County Road Commission, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(2)  Storm drainage. All streets shall provide for storm drainage in accordance with standards and specifications prescribed by the Township Engineer. Where county drains are included in the proposed plat, a letter or document of approval from the County Drain Commissioner shall be submitted by the proprietor. 
(3)  Septic tanks and private sewage systems. Septic tanks or private sewage systems with a central plant must meet standards and specifications prescribed by the Township Engineer, the County Health Department and/or the State Department Of Environmental Quality (DEQ), and a letter or document of approval from the County Health Department and the DEQ must be submitted by the proprietor. 
(4)  Water supply. Each lot shall be serviced with an adequate source of water supply, subject to the standards and specifications of the Township Engineer and the County Health Department. 
(5)  Street signs. For the proper identification of streets, the subdivider shall provide and erect street signs at all intersections, which signs shall meet the standards of the County Road Commission and the Township Board. 
(6)  Other improvements. The requirements for curb and gutter, sidewalks, lighting, crosswalks, street trees, driveways, etc., shall be as determined by the Township Planning Commission and/or the Township Board, upon due deliberation of the merits and needs of each individual subdivision. Public utilities must be placed underground and stubbed at the property line, and otherwise placed in accordance with the requirements of the County Road Commission. The consideration of sidewalk requirements should include a need for providing maximum safety for children playing, protection of children walking to and from schools and parks, and provision for adults and children walking to and from neighborhood shopping and bus stops. Street trees, if required, shall be at least three inches in diameter as measured six inches above the crown, and located on residential lots between the right-of-way line and the curbline at a spacing of one tree per each full 50-foot increment of lot frontage. The trees shall be species which are resistant to damage and disease, and do not cause interference with underground utilities or visibility at street intersections. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 406, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-139. - Guarantee of completing of improvements required. 
In lieu of the actual installation of required public improvements, the Township Board, upon recommendation of the Planning Commission, may permit the subdivider to provide a financial guarantee of performance of the requirements of this division, of the County Road Commission, County Drain Commissioner or any other agency responsible for the administration, operation and maintenance of the applicable public improvement, provided, a cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit is deposited as follows: 
(1)  Treasurer, escrow agent or trust company. A cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit, acceptable to the Township Board, shall accrue to the Township. Such deposits shall be made with the Township treasurer, or deposited with a responsible escrow agent or trust company, subject to the approval of the Township Board. 
(2)  Dollar value. The dollar value of the cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit shall be equal to the total estimated cost of construction of the specific public improvement, including contingencies, as estimated by the Township Board. 
(3)  Escrow time. The escrow time for the cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit, to the extent of the cost of the completed portion of the public improvement, shall be in accordance with a previously entered into agreement. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 407, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-140. - Condition of Township approval of final plat; financial guarantees. 
(a)  Approval condition. With respect to financial guarantees, the approval of all final subdivision plats shall be considered upon the accomplishment of one of the following: 
(1)  The construction of improvements required by this division shall have been completed by the subdivider and approved by the Township Board. 
(2)  Surety acceptable to the Township shall have been filed in the form of a cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit. 
(b)  Special agreements. A special agreement shall be entered into between the subdivider and the Township Board where street trees and streetlights have been required by the Township Board. 
(c)  Inspection of public improvements under construction. Before approving a final plat and constructions plans and specifications for public improvements, an agreement between the subdivider and the Township Board shall be made to provide for checking or inspecting the construction and its conformity to the submitted plans. 
(d)  Failure to complete the construction of a public improvement. If the subdivider shall, in any case, fail to complete such work within such period of time as required by the conditions of the guarantee for the completion of public improvements, it shall be the responsibility of the Township Board to proceed to have such work completed. In order to accomplish the completion of such work, the Township Board shall reimburse itself for the cost and expense thereof by appropriating the cash deposit, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit which the subdivider may have deposited, or may take such steps as may be necessary to require performance under this division, and as included in a written agreement between the Township Board and the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 408, 8-9-1972)  
Secs. 18-141—18-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DIVISION OF LAND IN RECORDED PLAT AND UNPLATTED PARCEL 
 
Sec. 18-161. - In general. 
The provisions of this division shall govern the partitioning or dividing of lots, outlots or other parcels of land in a recorded plat, subject to the provisions of section 263 of the land division act (MCL 560.263). 
(Ord. No. 8A, art. V(intro. ¶), 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-162. - Recorded plats, unplatted parcels and utility easements. 
(a)  The Township may permit the partitioning or dividing of lots, outlots or other parcels of land in recorded plats into not more than four parts. Such lots, outlots or parcels shall conform to the minimum lot width and area requirements of the zoning district in which the recorded plat is located. In areas not served by a public sewer or public water system, such partitioning or dividing shall not create lots, outlots or parcels which do not meet the minimum lot width and area requirements of the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101). In all cases, the most restrictive provisions of either chapter 38, zoning, or the land division act shall apply. 
(b)  The Township may permit the partitioning or dividing of unplatted parcels of land, provided, such partitioning or dividing complies with the land division act. Such partitioning or dividing shall result in the creation of parcels which conform to the minimum lot width and area requirements of the zoning district in which the parcel is located. 
(c)  No lot, outlot or parcel in a recorded plat or unplatted parcel shall be approved for partitioning or dividing without adequate provisions being made for utility easements. Where such utility easements are needed, written evidence of the availability of utility easements shall be submitted to the Township Board prior to approval. The location of utility easements shall be shown on the illustrative sketch which accompanies the application. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 500, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 500, 7-6-1983) 
State Law reference— Easements, MCL 560.190; lots, MCL 560.263.  
Sec. 18-163. - Lots divided into two. 
A lot, outlot or parcel may be divided into not more than two new lots, outlots or parcels, upon application to, and approval by, the Township Supervisor. The fact of such a division shall be noted upon the Township assessment roll and thereafter each separate parcel shall be considered to be a single lot, outlot or parcel for tax assessment and all other purposes. No such division shall be permitted unless each separate parcel meets the minimum requirements of chapter 38, zoning, including requirements as to width, area and open spaces. In cases where water, sewer or other services have been installed within the plat by special assessment and the lot, outlot or parcel proposed to be divided has been assessed therefor, no division shall be permitted unless the applicant agrees in writing to pay into the special assessment district an additional amount to be determined by the supervisor or the assessor representing the increased share of the special assessment district which should be borne by the lot, outlot or parcel as the result of increased benefit received by such lot, outlot or parcel when divided into two separate lots, outlots or parcels. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 501, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-164. - Land detached in a recorded plat. 
Land may be detached from one lot, outlot or parcel and added to another lot, outlot or parcel upon application to, and approval by, the Township Supervisor. The fact of such a division shall be noted upon the Township assessment roll and thereafter the enlarged lot, outlot or parcel shall be considered to be a single lot, outlot or parcel for tax assessment and all other purposes. No such division shall be permitted unless the remainder of the lot, outlot or parcel from which the part was taken meets the minimum requirements of chapter 38, zoning, including requirements as to width, area and open spaces. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 502, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 502, 7-6-1983)  
Sec. 18-165. - Division into two, three or four lots in a recorded plat. 
(a)  A lot, outlot or parcel may be divided into two, three or four separate lots, outlots or parcels upon application to, and approval by, the Planning Commission. A survey showing such proposed divisions, prepared by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor, and including a proper legal description of each separate lot, outlot or parcel proposed, shall be submitted with the application. The application shall be filed with the clerk at least 12 days prior to the regular Planning Commission meeting at which the applicant is scheduled to appear. A copy of the application and the survey may be forwarded to the Township Planner for recommendation. As soon as practical, the matter shall be placed upon the agenda of the next meeting of the Planning Commission. Should the Planning Commission approve the requested division, it shall notify the Township Supervisor or assessor and the fact of such division shall be noted upon the Township assessment roll and thereafter the divided portions of the lot, outlot or parcel shall be considered to be separate lots, outlots or parcels for tax assessment and all other purposes. 
(b)  No such division shall be permitted unless each of the parts into which such lot, outlot or parcel is to be divided meets the minimum requirements of chapter 38, zoning, including requirements as to width, area and open spaces. In such cases where water, sewer or other services have been installed within the plat by special assessment and the lot proposed to be divided has been assessed therefor, no division shall be permitted unless the applicant agrees in writing to pay into the special assessment district an additional amount to be determined by the supervisor or assessor representing the increased share of the divided lot, outlot or parcel due to increased benefits received by such lot, outlot or parcel when dividing the lot, outlot or parcel into two, three or four lots, outlots or parcels. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 503, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 503, 7-6-1983)  
Sec. 18-166. - Division of unplatted parcels. 
(a)  Application. The partitioning or dividing of unplatted parcels into two or three parts shall require the joint approval of the supervisor, assessor and building official. The partitioning or dividing of unplatted parcels into four or more parts shall require the approval of the Planning Commission. The application shall be filed with the clerk at least 12 days prior to the regularly scheduled Planning Commission meeting at which the applicant is scheduled to appear. A copy of the application may be forwarded to the Township Planner for recommendation. 
(b)  Zoning compliance. No application for the partitioning or dividing of unplatted parcels shall be approved unless the minimum requirements of chapter 38, zoning, are met. 
(c)  Access. No parcel shall be created unless accessibility is provided by either a public road or private road construction on a permanent, unobstructed easement. All private roads shall be constructed in accordance with chapter 38, article X, private roads. 
(d)  Utility easements. No application for the partitioning or dividing of unplatted parcels shall be approved without adequate provisions being made for utility easements. Where such utility easements are needed, written evidence of their availability shall be submitted prior to approval. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 504, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 504, 7-6-1983)  
Sec. 18-167. - Review fees. 
The applicant shall be required to pay any actual costs incurred by the Township in the review of an application for division of land. Such costs may include the review fees of the Township Planner, Township Engineer or Township Attorney. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 505, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 505, 7-6-1983)  
Sec. 18-168. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by any action of the Township Supervisor, assessor or Planning Commission under this division shall be entitled to a hearing before the Township Board. Such hearing shall be requested in writing and shall be held at the next meeting of the Township Board occurring not less than ten days after filing of the request. The Township Board may, after hearing, modify or reverse any decision of the Township Supervisor, Township Assessor or Planning Commission. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 506, 8-9-1972; Ord. No. 8A-1, § 506, 7-6-1983)  
Secs. 18-169—18-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - VARIANCES 
 
Sec. 18-191. - Generally. 
(a)  The Township Planning Commission may recommend to the Township Board a variance from the provisions of this article upon a finding that undue hardship may result from strict compliance with specific provisions or requirements of this article or that application of such provision or requirement is impracticable. The Planning Commission shall only recommend variances that it deems necessary to, or desirable for, the public interest. In making its findings, as required in this section, the Planning Commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be recommended unless the Planning Commission finds, after a meeting, that: 
(1)  There are such special circumstances or conditions affecting the property that the strict application of the provisions of this article would clearly be impracticable or unreasonable. In such cases, the subdivider shall first state his reasons in writing as to the specific provision or requirement involved and submit such reasons to the Planning Commission. 
(2)  The granting of the specified variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the area in which such property is situated. 
(3)  Such variance will not violate the provisions of the state land division act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(4)  Such variance will not have the effect of nullifying the interest and purpose of this article and the comprehensive development plan of the Township. 
(b)  The Planning Commission shall include its findings and the specific reasons for such findings in its report of recommendations to the Township Board and shall also record its reasons and actions in its minutes. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 600, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-192. - Topographical and physical limitation variance. 
Where, in the case of a particular proposed subdivision, it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of this article would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography, other physical conditions or other such conditions which are not self-inflicted, or that such conditions would result in inhibiting the achievement of the objectives of this article, the Planning Commission may recommend to the Township Board that variance modification or a waiver of the requirements of this article be granted. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 601, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-193. - Planned residential developments. 
The following requirements apply in addition to all other requirements of this article where a preliminary plat is filed for approval as a planned residential development under chapter 38, zoning: 
(1)  Statement of principles. Consideration by the Planning Commission and the Township Board of proposed optional use of planned residential developments shall reflect the following basic principles: 
a.  The planned residential development provisions of chapter 38, zoning, provide an optional method of subdividing property, and approval of any planned residential development is subject to the discretion of the Township. 
b.  Particular attention shall be given to the effect of a planned residential development upon the immediate area, where the character of the area has been established by previous development. Major attention shall be given by the Planning Commission and the Township Board to the benefits to be derived by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the Township because of the planned residential development, with minor consideration to be given to the proprietor. 
c.  The following objectives, set forth in chapter 38, zoning, shall govern the approval or disapproval of the proposed planned residential development: 
1.  Provide a more desirable living environment by preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks, hills and similar natural assets. 
2.  Encourage developers to use a more creative approach in the development of a residential area. 
3.  Encourage a more efficient, aesthetic and desirable use of the land, while recognizing a reduction in development costs and allowing the developer to bypass natural obstacles on the site. 
4.  Encourage the provision of open space within a reasonable distance of all lot development so benefits may accrue to the subdivision and further encourage the development of recreational facilities and areas. 
(2)  The application for approval of a planned residential development shall contain the following information, in addition to the information required by other sections of this article: 
a.  The Township Planner shall review and render an opinion upon the proposed planned residential development from the materials furnished and from visits to the site, or such other information as he may deem necessary, and render his opinion with respect to the following: 
1.  The suitability of the proposed open land for the purposes proposed. 
2.  The need for the proposed uses in the general area. 
3.  The location and layout of the open spaces with relation to the lots within the subdivision. 
4.  The effect upon neighboring areas which would result by the planned residential development and the appropriateness of the development of the lot sizes proposed under the planned residential development in the particular area involved. 
5.  Any other factors related to the development and proper design of the proposed subdivision. 
b.  The Township Attorney shall review the proposed planned residential development and render his opinion with respect to the following: 
1.  The proposed manner of holding title to the open land. 
2.  The proposed manner of payment of taxes. 
3.  The proposed method of regulating the use of the open land. 
4.  The proposed method of maintenance of property and financing thereof. 
5.  Any other factors related to the legal or practical problems of ownership, use and maintenance of the open land. 
(3)  If the Planning Commission is satisfied that the proposed planned residential development meets the letter and spirit of chapter 38, zoning, and should be approved, it shall recommend tentative approval of the plat, with the conditions upon which such approval should be based. Thereafter, the Township Board shall take action upon such application in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(4)  If the commission is not satisfied that the proposed planned residential development meets the letter and spirit of chapter 38, zoning, or finds that the approval of such planned residential development will be detrimental to existing development in the general area and should not be approved, it shall communicate such disapproval to the Township Board, with the reasons for such disapproval. The proprietor shall be entitled to a hearing upon such proposal before the Township Board upon written request for such hearing filed with the Township Clerk. 
(5)  If the Township Board gives preliminary approval to the proposed planned residential development, it shall instruct the Township Attorney to prepare a contract, setting forth the conditions upon which such approval is based, which contract, after approval by the Township Board, shall be entered into between the Township and the proprietor prior to the approval of any final plat, based upon the approved preliminary plat. 
(6)  At the time of application for final approval, the proprietor shall deposit cash or its equivalent in the amount of the estimated cost of the proposed improvements to the open land guaranteeing the completion of such improvements within a time to be set by the Township Board. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 602, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-194. - Natural features. 
The natural features and character of lands must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features, such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property, if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers, where appropriate, shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 602.1, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-195. - Floodplains. 
Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by stormwater, shall require specific compliance with the land division act and its review by the state department of environmental quality. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 602.2, 8-9-1972)  
Sec. 18-196. - Applications. 
Applications for variances are available from the Office of the Township Clerk. Such applications shall be submitted in writing by the proprietor at the time the preliminary plat is submitted for tentative approval, and such applications shall be supplemented by such maps, plans or other data which may aid in the analysis of the conditions which prompt the request. 
(Ord. No. 8A, § 603, 8-9-1972)  
Secs. 18-197—18-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CONDOMINIUMS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Condominium act, MCL 559.101 et seq.; Township zoning act, MCL 125.271 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-231. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building envelope means the principal structure intended for a building site, together with any attached accessory structures (e.g., in a residential development, the term "building envelope" would refer to the house and any attached garage). 
Building site means the condominium unit, including the building envelope and the contiguous limited common area or element under and surrounding the building envelope, and shall be the counter part of "lot," as used in connection with a project developed under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
Condominium act means Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 et seq.). 
Condominium plan means the site, survey and utility plans, floor plans and sections, as appropriate, showing the existing and proposed structures and improvements, including the location thereof on the land, for any condominium development. The condominium subdivision plan shall show the size, location, area, vertical boundaries and volume for each unit comprised of enclosed air space. A number shall be assigned to each condominium unit. The condominium subdivision plan shall include the nature, location and approximate size of limited and general common elements. 
Condominium project and project mean a plan or project, consisting of not less than two condominium units, established in conformance with the condominium act. 
Condominium unit means that portion of the condominium project designed and intended for separate ownership and use, as described in the master deed, regardless of whether it is intended for residential, office, industrial, business, recreational, time share unit or any other type of use. 
Consolidating master deed means the final amended master deed for a contractible condominium project, an expandable condominium project or a condominium project containing convertible land or space, which final amended master deed fully describes the condominium project as completed. 
Contractible condominium means a condominium project from which any portion of the submitted land or buildings may be withdrawn pursuant to express provisions in the condominium documents and in accordance with this article and the condominium act. 
Conversion condominium means a condominium project containing condominium units, some or all of which were occupied before the establishment of the condominium project. 
Convertible area means a unit or a portion of the common elements of the condominium project referred to in the condominium units or general or limited common elements which may be created pursuant to express provisions in the condominium documents and in accordance with this article and the condominium act. 
Design standards means the area, height and placement regulations as set forth in article III of chapter 38, zoning, and incorporated by reference as part of this definition. 
Expandable condominium means a condominium project to which additional land may be added pursuant to express provisions in the condominium documents and in accordance with this article and the condominium act. 
Front yard setback shall be equal to the distance between the front line of the building site and the building envelope. 
General commons area means the common elements of a condominium development, other than the limited common elements. 
Limited common elements means a portion of a condominium common elements reserved in the master deed for the exclusive use of less than all of the co-owners. 
Master deed means the condominium document recording the condominium project as approved by the Township Board, to which is attached as exhibits and incorporated by reference the approved bylaws and condominium plan for the project. 
Mobile home condominium project means a condominium project upon which mobile homes are intended to be located upon separate sites, which constitute individual condominium units. 
Rear yard setback shall be equal to the distance between the rear line of the building site and the building envelope. 
Side yard setback shall be equal to the distance between the side line of the building site and the building envelope. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 1.7, 2-21-1990) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-232. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to regulate the creation and use of condominium ownership and condominium development so that, to the extent possible and as stated in this article, any proposed or existing condominium project shall be treated no differently by any law, regulation or ordinance of the Township which would apply to the project or development under a different form of ownership, and to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 1.2, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-233. - Legal authorization. 
This article is enacted pursuant to the statutory authority conferred by the condominium act, Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 et seq.), the township zoning act, Public Act No. 184 of 1943 (MCL 125.271 et seq.), and the township ordinances act, Public Act No. 246 of 1945 (MCL 41.181 et seq.), so that all developments utilizing any form of condominium subdivision of lands may be reviewed and approved by the Planning Commission and the Township Board. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 1.3, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-234. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to the creation, use and approval of condominium development after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 1.4, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-235. - Fees. 
The Township Board shall establish by resolution a schedule of fees to be charged to the petitioner with respect to application administration, planning and engineering review, and final inspection of condominium developments. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 1.5, 2-21-1990)  
Secs. 18-236—18-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONDOMINIUM PLAN REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 18-261. - Required information. 
Concurrently with notice required to be given to the Township pursuant to section 71 of the condominium act (MCL 559.171), a person intending to develop a condominium project shall provide the following information with respect to the project, when a tentative preliminary plan is submitted: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of: 
a.  All persons with an ownership interest in the land on which the condominium project will be located, together with a description of the nature of each person's interest (for example, fee owner, optionee or land contract vendee). 
b.  All engineers, attorneys, architects or registered land surveyors associated with the project. 
c.  The developer or proprietor of the condominium project. 
(2)  The legal description of the land on which the condominium project will be developed, together with appropriate tax identification numbers. 
(3)  The acreage content of the land on which the condominium project will be developed, and a notation of the acreage to be dedicated as public right-of-way. 
(4)  The purpose of the project (e.g., residential, commercial, industrial, etc.). 
(5)  The approximate number of condominium units to be developed on the subject parcel. 
(6)  Whether or not a community water system is contemplated. 
(7)  Whether or not a community septic system is contemplated. 
(8)  A floodplain plan, where appropriate. 
(9)  A site plan showing the location, area and dimensions of all building envelopes, building sites (limited commons areas and general commons areas). 
(10)  A utility plan showing all sanitary sewer, water and storm sewer lines and easements granted to the Township for installation, repair and maintenance of all utilities. 
(11)  Stormwater management plan, including all lines, swales, drains, basins and other facilities, including appropriate documentation. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.1, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-262. - Streets. 
All building sites shall have direct access to a public road right-of-way or private road built to the County Road Commission's standards. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.2, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-263. - Encroachments. 
Encroachment of one condominium unit upon another, including the building envelope and limited common area, as described in section 40 of the condominium act (MCL 559.140), shall be prohibited by the condominium bylaws and recorded as part of the master deed. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.3, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-264. - Relocation of boundaries. 
The relocation of boundaries, as described in section 48 of the condominium act (MCL 559.148), shall conform to all design standards for the district in which the project is located and shall be approved by the zoning administrator, and such requirement shall be made part of the bylaws and recorded as part of the master deed. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.4, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-265. - Subdivision of condominium units. 
All individual condominium units shall conform to the design standards for minimum lot width, lot area and the building setback requirements provided by ordinance, and shall be approved by the Township Board. Such requirements shall be made part of the bylaws and recorded as part of the master deed. All condominium projects shall be located in the appropriate zoning district for their intended use and shall comply with all zoning standards. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.5, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-266. - Mobile home condominium projects. 
Mobile home condominium projects shall conform to all requirements of this article and shall be located only in RMA residential mobile home districts. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.6, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-267. - Updating information. 
The information required in this division shall be furnished to the building inspector and shall be kept updated until such time as a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.7, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-268. - Master deed. 
The condominium project developer or proprietor shall furnish the building inspector with one copy of the proposed recorded master deed and two copies of a legal survey. The legal survey shall be reviewed by the Township Engineer for compliance with Township ordinances. The Township Attorney shall review the master deed for its compliance with the approved plan. Fees for such review shall be established by resolution of the Township Board and shall be separate from all other fees. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.8, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-269. - Building site, mobile home site and recreational site monuments and markers. 
All condominium projects which consist in whole or in part of condominium units which are building sites, mobile home sites or recreational sites shall be marked with monuments as provided under the condominium act (MCL 559.407). The Township Board may waive the placing of any of the required monuments and markers for a reasonable time, not to exceed one year, on the condition that the proprietor deposits with the Township Clerk cash, a certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit, running to the Township, whichever the proprietor selects, in an amount not less than $25.00 per monument and not less than $100.00 in total. Such cash, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit shall be returned to the proprietor upon receipt of a certificate by a surveyor that the monuments and markers have been placed as required within the time specified. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.9, 2-21-1990) 
State Law reference— Survey requirements, MCL 560.125.  
Sec. 18-270. - Boundary monuments. 
All condominium projects shall be marked at their boundaries with monuments meeting the requirements of section 18-269. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.10, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-271. - Compliance with federal, state and local law. 
All condominium projects shall comply with federal and state statutes and local ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2.11, 2-21-1990)  
Secs. 18-272—18-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 18-291. - Site plan review and approval—Prior to recording master deed. 
Prior to the recording of the master deed as required by section 72 of Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.172), the condominium project shall undergo site plan review and approval pursuant to chapter 38, article II, division 2. In addition, the Township shall require appropriate engineering plans and inspections prior to the issuance of any certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.1, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-292. - Same—Prior to expansion or conversion. 
Prior to expansion or conversion of a condominium project to additional land, the new phase of the project shall undergo site plan review and approval pursuant to chapter 38, article II, division 2, and all other applicable ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.2, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-293. - State and county approval of freshwater system and wastewater disposal system. 
The developer or proprietor of the condominium project shall establish that appropriate state and county approvals have been received with regard to the freshwater system and the wastewater disposal system for the proposed project. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.3, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-294. - Temporary occupancy. 
The Township Supervisor may allow occupancy of the condominium project before all improvements required by this article are installed, provided that a bond is submitted in a sufficient amount and type to provide for the installation of improvements before the expiration of the temporary occupancy permit without expense to the Township. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.4, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-295. - Three-phase approval process. 
Approval under this division shall be required as a condition for the right to construct, expand or convert a condominium project in the Township. The approval process shall involve the following three phases: 
(1)  Tentative preliminary plan approval. 
(2)  Final preliminary plan approval. 
(3)  Final engineering plan approval. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.5, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-296. - Tentative preliminary plan. 
(a)  Tentative preliminary plan submittals must be received by the Township Clerk at least 21 days prior to the next regularly scheduled Planning Commission meeting. The Township Clerk shall not place the submittal on the agenda until all required information has been properly provided. Once the submittal is officially placed on the agenda, the Planning Commission shall have 60 days to approve, conditionally approve, or deny with findings in fact, the petition. 
(b)  A developer of a condominium project shall initially submit to the Township Clerk 20 copies of a proper and complete application for a tentative preliminary plan and shall provide all required information described in section 18-261. The plan shall also contain the name and address of the developer, and the name, address and seal of the engineer who prepared the plan, all legibly printed or typewritten. Qualified persons may assist in the preparation of the development plan or accompanying documents, to assist in the representation of the type and scope of the development plan. 
(c)  When the Township Clerk finds the application, the tentative preliminary plan and the supporting documentation to be complete as required in subsection (a) of this section, the tentative preliminary plan shall be placed on the agenda of the next regular meeting of the Planning Commission. 
(d)  The Planning Commission shall review the tentative preliminary plan and the comments of the Township Planners, engineer and attorney, and shall recommend approval, denial or grant conditional approval subject to specified modifications and changes to be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(1)  Should the approval be conditional, such conditions shall be met to the satisfaction of the Planning Commission within the time set by the Planning Commission, or the plan will be recommended for denial. 
(2)  Should the Planning Commission recommend denial of the tentative preliminary plan, it shall record findings of fact, the reasons of rejection and requirements for tentative approval in its minutes. Copies of the minutes shall be sent to the proprietor and filed in the Office of the Township Clerk. 
(3)  Should the Planning Commission find that all conditions have been satisfactorily met and the tentative preliminary plan conforms to chapter 38, zoning, and this article, it shall recommend approval of the tentative preliminary plan to the Township Board. The chairman shall make a notation to that effect on each copy of the tentative preliminary plan, and make provisions and distribute copies thereof as follows: 
a.  One copy shall be returned to the proprietor. 
b.  One copy shall be retained as a matter of permanent record for the Planning Commission's files. 
c.  Two copies shall be forwarded to the Township Board. 
(e)  Upon receipt of the recommendations from the Planning Commission, the Township Board shall review thee tentative preliminary plan and shall approve and note its approval on the copy of the tentative preliminary plan to be returned to the proprietor, or set forth in writing its reasons for rejection and requirements for tentative approval. The Township Board may require the submission of other pertinent related data as it deems necessary. After such approval, the Township Clerk shall distribute approved copies of the tentative preliminary plan as follows: 
(1)  One copy shall be returned to the proprietor. 
(2)  One copy shall be retained as a matter of permanent record in the Township Board's files. 
(f)  The proprietor, upon receiving approval from the Township Board, shall submit the tentative preliminary plan to all authorities as required by the condominium act (MCL 559.101 et seq.). 
(g)  Tentative preliminary plan approval shall confer upon the developer a commitment of approval for a period of one year with regard to the size, shape and layout of building sites and street layout. Such tentative preliminary plan approval may be extended if applied for by the proprietor within the effective period and approved by the Township Board. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.6, 2-21-1990; Ord. No. 78A, § 1, 3-15-1995)  
Sec. 18-297. - Final preliminary plan. 
(a)  Following approval of the tentative preliminary plan, the developer shall submit an application for final preliminary plan approval in accordance with the requirements of division 2 of this article. In addition to any information required to be submitted under section 18-261, the developer shall include with the application for final preliminary plan approval, sufficient information for determination of whether the project conforms with all applicable laws, codes and ordinances, and the design requirements of article III, division 3 of this chapter, and any applicable rules and regulations adopted by other governmental agencies having jurisdiction over site condominium plans. 
(b)  The application for final preliminary plan review shall also include a copy of the proposed master deed and any additional documentation to be recorded with the register of deeds for review and approval by appropriate Township consultants. 
(c)  Design standards shall be followed and sufficient information provided to document compliance. 
(d)  Review procedures for a final preliminary plan shall be the same as set forth in section 18-296(c)—(f), except the term "tentative" shall be changed to "final." 
(e)  Final preliminary plan approval shall be effective for a period of one year. Such approval may be extended if applied for by the developer within the effective period and granted by the Township Board. Approval will allow the developer to begin final design, specifications and bid documents for all required public improvements. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.7, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-298. - Final engineering plan. 
Following the grant of final preliminary plan approval, a developer shall submit an application for final engineering plan approval, which shall include plans and information in sufficient detail for the Township, and the Township Planners and the Township Engineer to determine compliance with all applicable laws, codes and ordinances for the construction of the project and the design requirements set forth in article III, division 3 of this chapter and any applicable rules and regulations adopted by other governmental agencies having jurisdiction over site condominium plans. Subject to applicable provisions of section 18-294, a building permit for construction shall be issuable at such time as the final engineering plan has been approved and all improvements for the project have been constructed; provided, however, the Planning Commission may determine that certain improvements need not be constructed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy on the condition that all improvements will be completed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, and the developer posts cash or a letter of credit, in the form and amount determined appropriate by the Township Board, following the advice of the Township Engineer, for the timely completion of such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.8, 2-21-1990)  
Sec. 18-299. - Additional regulations. 
(a)  There shall be compliance with other provisions of this article, all requirements of article III of this chapter, chapter 38, zoning, and other applicable ordinances, with the understanding that reference to the term "lot" in such regulations means and refers to a "building site" as that term is defined in section 18-231, and reference to the term "building" (meaning principal building) or "structure" (meaning principal structure) means and refers to a "building envelope" as that term is defined in section 18-231. In the review of tentative preliminary plans, final preliminary plans and final engineering plans, it is recognized that it may not be feasible to precisely apply traditional definitions and measures which would be made for developments proposed under, for example, the land division act. However, the review of plans submitted under this article shall be accomplished with the objective and intent of achieving the same results as if the improvements were being proposed pursuant to the land division act. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of building permits, the developer shall demonstrate approval by county and state entities having jurisdiction with regard to any aspect of the development, including, without limitation, public roads, stormwater management, water supply, sewage disposal, wetlands and floodplains. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of certificates of occupancy, the developer shall demonstrate approval by any other governmental entities having jurisdiction, and the Township Supervisor shall determine that all improvements have been completed in accordance with the approved plan. Occupancy permits may be issued prior to full completion, and such a temporary certificate of occupancy may be granted for a specified period, on the condition that a suitable letter of credit or corporate surety bond, issued by a company licensed to do business in the county, in the form and amount approved by the director, following the advice of Township consultants. The security shall be in an amount based upon either a contract executed by the Township Engineer or as determined appropriate by the supervisor. 
(d)  The fees for all reviews shall be established by resolution of the Township Board. 
(e)  Any proposed amendment of a master deed shall be submitted for review by the Township Supervisor. If such proposed amendment appears to have no direct or indirect effect upon any matter reviewed or approved under this division, such amendment shall be approved by the Township Supervisor. Otherwise, the Township Supervisor shall submit such amendment to the Planning Commission and Township Board for review and approval pursuant to this article, provided, such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.9, 2-21-1990)  
Chapter 20 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes:
