DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 34-81—34-100. - Reserved.  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 34-101. - Authority, purpose, and objectives. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this Article to protect the public health and safety by abating and preventing pollution through the regulation and control of the disposal of wastewater and the quality and quantity of wastes admitted to be discharged into the wastewater collection system of the Township and the county. 
(b)  It is the further purpose of this article to enable the Township to provide a POTW system for properties within the Township and to comply with the requirements of all applicable federal, state and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-102. - Control authority and legal authority. 
The Green Oak Charter Township Board of Trustees is defined as the control and legal authority of the POTW. The POTW shall have the legal authority enforceable in federal or state courts that authorizes or enables the publicly owned treatment works to apply and to enforce the regulations of the Clean Water Act and any rules or regulations implementing those sections. The Township Board of Trustees shall have the authority to: 
(a)  Deny or condition new or increased contributions of pollutants, or changes in the nature of pollutants, to the POTW by nondomestic users where the contributions do not meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements or where the contributions would cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit. 
(b)  Require compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements by nondomestic users. 
(c)  Control, through permit, the contribution to the POTW by each significant industrial user to ensure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. All industrial users are required to apply for and receive a permit from the Township prior to discharging into the Township's POTW or POTW. Permits shall be enforceable and contain, at a minimum, the following conditions: 
(1)  A statement of the duration of the permit, which shall not be for more than five years. 
(2)  A permit issued by Green Oak Charter Township shall not be transferred to any other user, including through the sale of property. 
(3)  Effluent limits based on applicable general pretreatment standards, local limits, state and local laws. 
(4)  Self-monitoring, sampling, reporting, notification, and record keeping requirements, including identification of the pollutants to be monitored, sampling location, sampling frequency, and sample type, based on the applicable general pretreatment standards, local limits, state and local laws. 
(d)  Require the development of a compliance schedule by each nondomestic user for the installation of technology required to meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements and require the submission of all notices and self-monitoring reports from nondomestic users that are necessary to assess and assure compliance by nondomestic users with pretreatment standards and requirements, including the reports required in Part 23 of the Rules of the State of Michigan. 
(e)  Carry out all inspection, surveillance, and monitoring procedures necessary to determine, independent of information supplied by nondomestic users, compliance or noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements by nondomestic users. Representatives of the POTW shall be authorized to enter the premises of any nondomestic user in which a discharge source or treatment system is located or in which records are required to be kept under R323.2310 to assure compliance with pretreatment standards. The authority shall be at least as extensive as the authority provided in the Clean Water Act and Part 23 Rules of the State of Michigan. 
(f)  Obtain remedies for noncompliance by any nondomestic user with any pretreatment standard and requirement. The POTW shall seek injunction relief for noncompliance by nondomestic users and shall seek civil and criminal penalties as authorized by state law and local law for each violation by nondomestic users of pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(g)  The POTW and Township Board of Trustees shall have the authority, after informal notice to the property owner, to immediately and effectively halt or prevent any discharge to the POTW which presents or may present an endangerment to the environment or which threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW. 
(h)  To require nondomestic users to comply with the pretreatment standards and local limits as set forth in this article. 
(i)  To require that nondomestic users prepare a slug control plan, if necessary, per Part 23 Rules of the State of Michigan. 
(j)  Enforcement of pretreatment violations will be in accordance with the current adopted Township's Enforcement Response Plan. However, the Township Board may take other action against any user when circumstances warrant. Further, the Township Board is empowered to take more than one enforcement action against any noncompliant user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-103. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Act means Clean Water Act, which is defined in this article. 
Approval authority means the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality. 
Approved pretreatment program means an industrial pretreatment program administered by a publicly owned treatment works, in this case the Township, which meets the criteria established in R323.2306 and which has been approved by the approval authority in accordance with R323.2308. 
Authorized representative of industrial user means a: 
(a)  Principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president, if the industrial user is a corporation; 
(b)  General partner or proprietor, if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; or 
(c)  Duly authorized representative of the individual designated in subsections (1) and (2) of this definition, if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the direct discharge originates. 
Average daily flow means a reasonable measure of the average daily flow for a 30-day period. 
Benefited properties means all properties which will derive benefit from the construction of a sewer improvement. 
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
Board shall mean the Board of Trustees of Green Oak Charter Township, a Livingston County Municipality. 
Bypass means the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of an industrial user's treatment facility needed for compliance with pretreatment standards. 
Categorical industrial user means all non-domestic users subject to categorical pretreatment standards. 
Categorical pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act, 33 USC §1317, which apply to specific category of non-domestic users and which appear in 40 CFR, parts 405-471. 
Cesspool means an underground pit into which household sewage or other untreated wastewater is discharged and from which the liquid seeps into the surrounding soil or is otherwise removed. 
Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means a measure of oxygen-consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater. COD is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specified test. It does not differentiate between stable and unstable organic matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen demand. Such term is also referred to as "oxygen consumed (OC)" and "dichromate oxygen consumed (DOC)," respectively. 
Clean Water Act means the federal Water Pollution Control Act, 33 USC §1251 et seq., as amended. 
Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff (stormwater) and wastewater. 
Community wastewater utility systems means a facility which is owned by a non-governmental entity and is designed, constructed, operated, and maintained to transport, collect, process, and treat wastewater from more than one single-family residential dwelling. 
Compatible pollutant means a substance amenable to treatment in the publicly owned treatment works (POTW) treatment plant, such as biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the Township's NPDES permit, if the POTW was designed to treat such pollutants to a substantial degree. Examples of such additional pollutants may include chemical oxygen demand, total organic carbon, phosphorus and phosphorus compounds, nitrogen compounds, fats, and oils and greases of animal or vegetable origin. 
Composite sample means a series of representative samples taken over a specific time period, which are then combined into one sample for testing purposes. 
Control authority means the POTW and in this case means the Township Board of Trustees. 
Cooling water means the water discharged from any use, such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Debt service charge means the charges levied to customers of the wastewater system, which are used to pay principal, interest and administrative costs of retiring the debt incurred for construction of the wastewater system. 
Department means the Township sewer department. 
Development documents means (a) for a condominium project, the master deed and bylaws provided by Act No. 59 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended; and (b) with regard to subdivisions or other developments, deed restrictions and/or restrictive covenants. 
Direct capital connection fee means the fee charged to a person who connects a premises directly to the POTW. 
Direct discharge means the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state. 
Director means the Township Supervisor or his/her authorized representative. 
Discharge means any direct or indirect discharge of any waste, waste effluent, wastewater, pollutant, or any combination into any of the waters of the State or upon the ground. 
EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
Fats, oils, grease (FOG) means fats, wax, grease or oil concentrations of animal or vegetable origin (living sources). Garbage means the solid waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Grab sample means a sample which is taken from a wastewater stream on a one-time basis, with no regard to the flow in the wastewater stream and without consideration of time. 
Grease trap means a tank of suitable size and materials, located in a sanitary sewer line, and designed to contain grease and oily wastes from the wastewater. 
Health department means the Livingston County Department of Public Health. 
Holding tank wastewater means any wastewater from holding tanks, such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
Incompatible pollutant means any pollutant which is not a compatible pollutant. 
Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants into the POTW, including holding tank wastewater discharged into the system. 
Industrial user means a user connected to the POTW that generates waste from an operation or process of the manufacturing and/or making goods including but not limited the industrial categories as listed in the industrial user permit application. 
Interference means a discharge, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, to which both of the following provisions apply: 
(a)  The discharge inhibits or disrupts the Township's POTW treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal. 
(b)  Pursuant to paragraph (i) of this subdivision, the discharge is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation, or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder, or more stringent state or local regulations: 
(1)  Section 405 of the Clean Water Act; 
(2)  The Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 USC §6901 et seq., including title II, more commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, and including state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act; 
i.  The Clean Air Act, 42 USC §7401 et seq. 
ii.  The Toxic Substances Control Act, 15 USC §2601 et seq. 
iii.  The Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, 33 USC §1401 et seq. 
Laboratory determination means the measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastewaters in accordance with the methods contained in the latest edition at the time of any such measurement, test or analysis of the Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Waste Water, a joint publication of the American Public Health Association, the American Waterworks Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation, or in accordance with any other method prescribed by the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to such latest edition. 
Lateral means a pipe or conduit, located within the public right-of-way or an easement granted or dedicated to the public, which receives wastewater from abutting properties. 
Local limit means a specific prohibition or limit set by a POTW on discharges by a nondomestic user. 
MDEQ means the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality or any successor. 
Municipality means a county, city, village, township, district, association, or other public body created by or under state law, or an agency or instrumentality of any of them, having jurisdiction over the disposal of wastewater. 
National Categorical Pretreatment Standard and pretreatment standard mean any federal regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA, which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit means a permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 USC §1342). 
National Prohibitive Discharge Standard and prohibitive discharge standard means any regulation developed under the authority of Section 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR 403.5. 
Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (NREPA) means the State of Michigan 1994 Act 451, MCL 324.101 et seq. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
New source means any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there is or may be a discharge and for which construction commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Clean Water Act will be applicable to the source if the standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with section 307(c), and if any of the following provisions apply: 
(a)  The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located. 
(b)  The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source. 
(c)  The production of wastewater-generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation is substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. The extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source and the extent of integration of the new facility with the existing plant should be considered in determining whether the process is substantially independent. 
Nondomestic user means an industry, commercial establishment, or other entity that discharges wastewater to a POTW other than, or in addition to, sanitary sewage. 
Normal domestic sewage (NDS) means wastewater which, when analyzed, shows a daily average concentration meeting the local limits. 
Nuisance means any condition or circumstance defined as a nuisance pursuant to state statute, at common law or in equity jurisprudence or Township ordinances, including this Article, as well as any condition or circumstance where wastewater or the effluent from any wastewater disposal facility or toilet device is exposed on the surface of the ground or is permitted to drain on or to the surface of the ground, into any ditch, storm sewer, lake or stream, or when the odor, appearance or presence of such material has an obnoxious or detrimental effect on or to the senses and/or health of persons, or when it shall obstruct the comfortable use, enjoyment or sale of adjacent and/or surrounding property. 
Off-site sewer mains means sewer mains constructed off the premises of the owner to be served, which are necessary to afford service to the premises from trunk sewers not adjacent to the premises. 
Operation and maintenance means all work, materials, equipment, utilities and other efforts required to operate and maintain the wastewater transportation and treatment system consistent with ensuring adequate treatment of wastewater to produce an effluent in compliance with the NPDES permit and other applicable state and federal regulations, and includes the cost of replacement. 
Pass through means a discharge that exits a publicly owned treatment works into state waters or groundwater in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, cause a violation of any requirement of the Act. 
Permit means an authorization, license, or equivalent control document and includes any of the following: 
(a)  An industrial user permit, which is a control document issued by the POTW that controls the wastewater discharges from industrial users into the publicly owned treatment works. 
(b)  A national pollutant discharge elimination system, which is a permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Clean Water Act to control wastewater discharges into the surface waters. 
(c)  A state permit, which is a permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Clean Water Act to control wastewater discharges of POTW to the groundwaters. 
pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions, expressed in moles per liter of solution. 
Pollutant means any of the following: 
(a)  Substances regulated by categorical standards; 
(b)  Substances discharged to POTW that are required to be monitored, are limited in the POTW's permit, this article, and/or identified in the industrial user permit. 
(c)  Substances for which control measures on nondomestic users are necessary to avoid restricting the POTW's approved residuals management program. 
(d)  Substances for which control measures on nondomestic users are necessary to avoid operational problems at the POTW. 
Pollution means the manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. 
Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) means the publicly owned treatment works (POTW), in this case under the legal authority of the Township Board. The POTW includes the wastewater treatment plants, pump stations, sanitary sewer system, etc. that make up the Township's sanitary sewer system and appurtenances. 
Premises and property mean the lands included within a single description as set forth from time-to-time on the Township tax roll as a single tax parcel in the name of a taxpayer at one address, but, in the case of platted lots, shall be limited to a single platted lot unless an existing building or structure is so located on more than one lot so as to make it a single description for purposes of assessment or conveyance. 
Pretreatment and treatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, the alteration of the nature of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to, or in lieu of, discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or process changes and other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d). 
Pretreatment program means a nondomestic user waste control program which is required in a POTW's wastewater discharge permit or order of the State of Michigan. The pretreatment program shall include, but not limited to, the following: this article, the Industrial Pretreatment Program Procedures, Enforcement Response Plan, Permit Application and Permit for Industrial User Sewer Connections and standard inspection form as adopted by the Township Board. 
Pretreatment requirement means any substantive or procedural requirement for related to pretreatment, other than a pretreatment standard, imposed on a nondomestic user for treating of wastewater prior to its inclusion in the POTW. 
Pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated in accordance with the Clean Water Act. This term includes prohibited discharges and local limits as defined in R323.2303 and categorical standards. 
Private sewage disposal facility means a facility for the transportation, collection, processing or treatment of wastewater, owned by a nongovernmental entity. Such term shall include septic systems, community wastewater utility systems, or any other device used in the disposal of sewage or human excreta. 
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sanitary sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Property owner means the owner of record of the freehold or the premises or lesser estate therein, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, trustee, lessee or other person, firm or corporation in control of a property. 
Public sanitary sewer means the publicly-owned pipe or conduit that conveys wastewater to the POTW treatment plant. 
Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) means a treatment works as defined by section 212 of the Act (33 USC §1292), which is owned, in this instance, by the Township. Such term includes any sanitary sewer that conveys wastewater to the POTW treatment plant. For the purposes of this Article, the term "POTW" shall also include any sanitary sewer that conveys wastewater to the POTW from persons outside the Township who are, by contract or agreement with the Township, users of the Township's POTW. 
Replacement means the replacement, in whole or in part, of any equipment, appurtenance and accessory in the wastewater transportation or treatment systems to ensure continuous collection and treatment of wastewater in accordance with the NPDES permit and other applicable state and federal regulations. 
Residential equivalent unit (R.E.U.) means the relationship between a single-family dwelling and other water or sewer customers as established by the unit factor tables adopted by the Township Board. A unit factor of one is considered to be a single-family household residence. Minimum charge is to be one unit for each connection. The total charge for each customer shall be calculated as the sum of the unit factors for the various usages at that location, times the current rates and charges for services. 
Restaurant means full service restaurants, fast food establishments, delis, cafeterias (including church and school facilities where commercial equipment is installed and the square footage and/or frequency of use indicates more than occasional use), meat distributors, food processing facilities, grocery stores with food preparation/service areas, bakeries, caterers, and/or other similar types of operations. 
Sanitary sewage means water-carried wastes from toilets, kitchen, laundry, bathing, or other facilities used for household purposes. 
Sanitary lead means the extension of the public sanitary sewer from the building in which wastewater originates to the public sanitary sewer or other place of disposal. The sanitary lead is the responsibility of the property owner. 
Seepage pit means a cistern or underground enclosure, constructed of concrete blocks, bricks or similar material loosely laid with open joints so as to allow the overflow or effluent to be absorbed directly into the surrounding soil. 
Septic system means the wastewater treatment or disposal device installed to service an individual home, business or industrial establishment that is not connected to the public sanitary sewer system. 
Septic tank means a watertight receptacle receiving wastewater and having an inlet and outlet designed to permit the separation of suspended solids from sewage and to permit such retained solids to undergo decomposition therein. 
Sewage means human excreta, and can, but not necessarily, be a component of wastewater. However, the terms "sewage" and "wastewater" are used interchangeably in this article. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit carrying wastewater and/or stormwater, surface water, and groundwater. 
Sewer service charge means the sum of the applicable user charges, surcharges and debt service charges 
Significant industrial user means either of the following: 
(a)  A nondomestic user subject to categorical pretreatment standards under 40 CFR 403 (1992) and 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N (1990). 
(b)  A nondomestic user to which one of the following provisions applies: 
(1)  The user discharges an average of 25,000 gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW, excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater. 
(2)  The user contributes waste from an industrial process that makes up 5% or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW. 
(3)  The user is designated as a significant industry user by the control authority on the basis that the user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(c)  Upon a finding that a nondomestic user meeting the criteria in paragraph (ii) of this subdivision has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the control authority may, at any time, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from a nondomestic user or POTW, determine that a nondomestic user is not a significant industrial user. 
Significant noncompliance means any of the following: 
(a)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined as results of analysis in which 66 percent or more of all of the measurements taken during a six-month period exceed, by any magnitude, the daily maximum limit or the average limit for the same pollutant parameter. 
(b)  Technical review criteria violations, defined as results of analysis in which 33 percent or more of all of the measurements for each pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the daily maximum limit of the average limit multiplied by the applicable technical review criteria. Technical review criteria equals 1.4 for conventional pollutants and 1.2 for all other pollutants, except pH. 
(c)  Any other violation of a pretreatment effluent limit, daily or maximum, or longer-term average that the control authority determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass-through, including endangering the health of publicly owned treatment works personnel, staff, or consultants or the general public. 
(d)  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment to human health, welfare, or the environment or has resulted in the POTW's exercise of its emergency authority under R323.2306(a) (vi) to halt or prevent the discharge. 
(e)  Failure to meet, within 90 days after the schedule date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a local control mechanism or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance. 
(f)  Failure to provide, within 30 days after the due date, required reports, such as baseline monitoring reports, 90-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules. 
(g)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance. 
(h)  Any other violation or group of violations that the control authority determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
Slug discharge means any discharge of a nonrouting, episodic nature, including an accidental spill or noncustomary batch discharge. 
Slug load means any substance released in a discharge at a rate and/or concentration which causes interference to a POTW. 
Storm sewer and storm drain mean a pipe or conduit which carries stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters, but excludes any type of wastewater. 
Stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
Structure in which wastewater originates and structure mean a building in which toilet, kitchen, laundry, bathing or other facilities which generate wastewater and are used for household, commercial, industrial or other purposes. 
Subsurface disposal field means a facility for the distribution of septic tank overflow or effluent below the ground surface through a line or a series of branch lines of drain tile laid with open joints to allow the overflow or effluent to be absorbed by the surrounding soil through the entire field. 
Surcharge means, as a part of the service charge, the additional charge to any customer discharging wastewater having a strength in excess of limits set forth herein, that may be required to be charged to cover the cost of treatment of such excess strength wastewater. 
Suspended solids means the solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids. 
Township means Green Oak Charter Township located in Livingston County, Michigan, which owns the POTW and is the control authority and legal authority. 
Toxic pollutant means any pollutant, or combination of pollutants, which is or can potentially be harmful to the public health or environment, including those listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Administrator of the EPA under the provisions of Section 307(a) of the Clean Water Act or other Acts. 
Trade secret means the whole or any portion or phase of any manufacturing proprietary process or method which is not patented, which is secret, which is useful in compounding an article of trade having a commercial value, and the secrecy of which the owner has taken reasonable measure to prevent from becoming available to persons other than those selected by the owner to have access for limited purposes. Trade secret shall not be construed, for purposed of these rules, to include any information regarding the quantum or character of waste products or their constituents discharged, or sought to be discharged, into the POTW. 
Uncontaminated industrial process water means water which does not come into contact with any substance used in, or incidental to, industrial processing operations and to which no chemical or other substance has been added. 
Upset means an exceptional incident in which a user unintentionally and temporarily is in a state of noncompliance with the requirements of this Article due to factors beyond the reasonable control of the user, excluding noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation thereof. 
User means the owner of a property from which wastewater is generated and/or any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the POTW. 
User charge means a charge levied on users of a POTW for the costs including, but not limited to, operation and maintenance of POTW, the cost of replacement and depreciation of the POTW facilities pursuant to the Clean Water Act; and shall also include other fees, fines, penalties referenced in this Ordinance. 
User class means the kind of users connected to sanitary sewers, including, but not limited to, residential, industrial, commercial, institutional and governmental. 
(a)  Commercial user means an establishment listed in the office of the management and budget's Standard Industrial Classification Manual (SICM), involved in a commercial enterprise, business or service which, based on a determination by the Township, discharges primarily segregated domestic wastewaters or wastewaters from sanitary conveniences and which is not a residential user or an industrial user. 
(b)  Governmental user means any federal, state or local government user of the wastewater treatment works. 
(c)  Industrial user means a user of the treatment works which discharges wastewater from industrial, manufacturing, trade or business processes, or from any structure with such characteristics, or distinct from their employee's domestic wastewaters or wastewaters from sanitary conveniences. 
(d)  Institutional user means any establishment listed in the SICM and involved in a social, charitable, religious or educational function, which, based on a determination by the Township, discharges primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastewaters from sanitary conveniences. 
(e)  Residential user means a user of a treatment works whose premises or buildings are used primarily as a domicile for one or more persons, including dwelling units, such as detached, semi-detached and row houses, mobile homes, apartments or permanent multifamily dwellings. Transit lodging is not included in this definition and is considered to be commercial. 
Wastewater means the wastewaters from industrial processes or domestic wastewaters from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into, or permitted to enter, the POTW. Wastewater can, but does not necessarily, contain sewage or human excreta. However, the terms "sewage" and "wastewater" are used interchangeably in this article. 
Watercourse means a channel, natural or artificial, in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
Waters of the state means all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or border upon the state, or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, §1-2.

(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-105—34-124. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Sewer Department 
 
Sec. 34-125. - Establishment. 
A sewer department for the Township may be established by resolution of the Township board. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-126. - Director. 
The construction, operation, management, maintenance, repair and control of the POTW, whether owned by the Township or operated under contract, may be under the control of a sewer director. The director shall be appointed by the Township Board and shall report to the Township Board. In the absence of an appointed Director, the Township Supervisor shall act as the Director. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, §2-61 et seq.  
Secs. 34-127—34-144. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Sewer Service Rates, Charges and Fees 
 
Sec. 34-145. - Rates, charges and fees established; applicability; basis. 
The rates for total sewer service charges and fees for recovery of costs from users of the POTW are to be established by resolution of the Township Board, which may be enacted apart from the published ordinances, as necessary, to ensure sufficiency of revenues in meeting operation, maintenance and replacement costs, as well as debt service. Such charges, fees and rates shall be made against each lot, parcel of land or premises which may have any sewer connection with the POTW, or which may otherwise discharge wastewater, either directly or indirectly, into such system, or any part thereof. Such charges shall be based upon the quantity of water used thereon or therein, service provided, user charges, surcharge or connection fee based on adopted R.E.U Unit Factor Table. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-146. - Rates, billing and collection. 
(a)  The rates, fees and charges for POTW service shall be charged to each lot or parcel of land, building or premises having any sewer connection to the POTW, on the basis of Residential Equivalent Units as calculated by the Township, except in cases where the character of the wastewater from a manufacturing or industrial plant, building or premises is such that unreasonable additional burden is placed upon the system, greater than that imposed by the normal domestic sewage delivered to the system plant, the additional cost of treatment created thereby shall be an additional charge over the regular rates set forth in this section, or the Township may, if it deems it advisable, compel such manufacturing or industrial plant, building or premises to pretreat and/or pretreat such wastewater in such a manner as shall be specified by the Township before discharging such wastewater into the POTW system. 
(b)  Billing for user charges shall be the Township's responsibility. All user charges shall be billed quarterly; however, the Township may bill and require payment on a monthly basis of any user with a residential equivalent unit factor of ten or greater or any user with a history of nonpayment or late payment. Bills shall be considered due as of the date billed and delinquent 30 days after the due date. 
All unpaid sewer charges which, upon September 30 of each year, have remained unpaid for 30 days shall be reported by the Township Treasurer's Department to the Township Board. The Township Board may authorize the placement of delinquent sewer charges on the property tax roll by Resolution. 
(c)  Unless otherwise adopted by resolution of the Township Board, the fees are: 
(1)  User charges: 
a.  Commodity charge/Quarterly Fee for Operations and Maintenance of POTW: $90.00 per R.E.U. 
b.  Connection Fee/Capital Charge: $4,500.00 per R.E.U 
(2)  An additional charge for laboratory testing of wastewater samples. The laboratory charge shall be for the cost thereof and will be determined for each user. 
(3)  Other fees as described herein. 
(d)  User charges shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the pretreatment program; 
(2)  Monitoring, inspection and surveillance procedures; 
(3)  Reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
(4)  Filing appeals; 
(5)  Consistent removal by the POTW of pollutants subject to federal pretreatment standards; 
(6)  Other charges as the POTW may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in this article; 
(7)  Additional charges may be made to compensate for the cost of treatment of pollutant loadings not normally treated at or in excess of those treated by the POTW; 
(8)  Additional charges for laboratory testing of wastewater. The laboratory charge shall be for the cost thereof and will be determined for each industrial user. 
(9)  Or any other costs not part of the normal operation of the POTW. 
(e)  Review. Users having a REU factor of more than one may be reviewed by the Township at least once each year. In the event of a change in use, the new REU factor may be applied retroactively to the date such use changed and shall apply to all charges to which such REU factor is applicable including, but not limited to, connection capacity (capital) charges and usage fees. Failure to specifically review, as provided in this Section, shall not cause such REU factor to be omitted and shall not be considered grounds for the discontinuance of such factor. 
(f)  Review of nondomestic users. For review of nondomestic users with meters or where the user has been required to install a meter to register flow or water usage, the REU unit factor for purposes of determining the rates and charges of such user may be reviewed and adjusted annually to assure the REU factor assigned to such user is compatible with use. The formula for determining the flow per REU for such users for purposes of determining the user charges for the next fiscal year shall be as follows: Average monthly flow during previous year divided by 260 gpd = flow per REU. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-147. - Nonpayment of bills, delinquencies, shutoff notice, late penalty. 
(a)  If payment is not received, or satisfactory arrangements have not been made, within 30 days of the due date on the bill, a shutoff notice will be sent by first class mail to inform the user that failure to make payment will result in termination of sewer service. If payment is not received or satisfactory arrangements have not been made within seven days after the shutoff notice is sent to the user, the sewer service shall be shut off. No sewer service that has been discontinued due to nonpayment shall be restored until all delinquent bills are paid or satisfactory arrangements for such payment are made. 
(b)  A late penalty fee of ten percent of all delinquent amounts due shall be applied to bills not paid within 30 days of the due date. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-148. - Collection of delinquent accounts. 
Charges for POTW service furnished to any premises within the Township shall also be a lien against the premises. Enforcement of such lien shall be made pursuant to the applicable statute. The lien remedy does not preclude any other remedy provided by law or allowed under this Article or this Ordinance. Premises outside the Township that are served by the Township's wastewater system that have delinquent bills will be certified to their governmental unit for collection as provided in the contract between the Township and governmental unit. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-149. - Annual audit. 
The rates and charges fixed in this Article are estimated to be sufficient to provide for the expenses of operation, maintenance and replacement of the POTW as are necessary to preserve the POTW in good repair and working order. Such rates and charges shall be fixed and revised from time-to-time as may be necessary to produce such amounts. The Township may review rates and charges annually. Based on such review, rates and charges may be revised as necessary to meet system expenses and to ensure that all users pay their proportionate share of operation, maintenance and equipment replacement costs. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-150. - Free service. 
No free service shall be allowed for any user of the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-151—34-171. - Reserved.  
DIVISION II. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS  
Subdivision I. - Discharge of Sewage Wastewater 
 
Sec. 34-172. - Restrictions and regulations. 
The discharge or depositing of wastewater shall be restricted and regulated as follows: 
(a)  No person shall discharge any wastewater upon any public or private property in the Township unless: 
(1)  The wastewater has been treated by a POTW treatment facility; and 
(2)  The placing or depositing of such wastewater has been specifically permitted and approved by the MDEQ. 
(b)  All users of the POTW system are prohibited from using sodium chloride-based agents in water softeners. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-173. - Private sewage disposal systems. 
No person shall construct, maintain or use any septic tank, seepage pit, toilet device, subsurface disposal field, privy, private vault, private sewage disposal facility, community wastewater utility system, or any other facility or device intended or used for the disposal of wastewater unless it is not dangerous to public health and is specifically permitted and approved by the health department, and, where appropriate, the MDEQ, drain commissioner, and/or Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-174. - Connection to sanitary sewer required. 
Any structure in which wastewater originates shall be connected to the available sanitary sewer within six months, or other time frames set forth by the Township Board, after publication by the Township of a legal notice of availability of a sanitary sewer in a newspaper of general circulation in the Township. For purposes of this section, a sanitary sewer shall be considered to be available by the Township, and when it is located in a right-of-way, easement, highway, street or public way which crosses, adjoins or abuts upon the property in question and passes not more than 200 feet at the nearest point from the structure in which the wastewater originates. For purposes of this section, the term "structure in which wastewater originates" means a building in which toilet, kitchen, laundry, bathing or other facilities that generate wastewater are used, or are available for use, for household, commercial, industrial or other purposes. If the structure in which wastewater originates has not been connected to an available sanitary sewer within such six-month period, then the Township shall require the connection to be made in accordance with Section 12754 of the Michigan Public Health Code (MCL 333.12754), or any similar successor statutory provision. In so proceeding, the Township shall have the rights and remedies provided in such Section 12754, as well as all rights and remedies provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-175. - Industrial wastewater. 
If an industry makes adequate provision for the disposal of its industrial wastewaters other than by discharging such wastewaters into the POTW, and if such disposal is approved by the MDEQ and all other governmental agencies having jurisdiction, then the Township Board may by resolution excuse such industry from depositing its industrial wastewaters into the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-176—34-195. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Sanitary Leads and Connections 
 
Sec. 34-196. - Permit required; inspection; responsibility for costs; liability for injury, loss or damage. 
(a)  No sanitary lead shall be covered until the Township has inspected and approved it as being of adequate and acceptable construction, size and location. 
(b)  The owner of a building or premises, or his/her authorized representative, shall be responsible, at his/her own cost, for the installation, connection and maintenance of the sanitary lead for such building or premises up to and including its connection with the POTW. 
(c)  The owner and, where appropriate, his/her authorized representative, shall indemnify and hold the Township and its employees, agents and representatives free and harmless from any and all liability or responsibility for all injury, loss or damage that may result, directly or indirectly, from the installation, connection or maintenance of the sanitary lead. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-197. - Permit application; permit and inspection fees; refusal to grant permit. 
(a)  Application for a permit to connect to the public sewer shall be made on appropriate forms provided by the Township. The application shall be supplemented by such plans, specifications or other information. 
(b)  The Township Board shall establish permit and inspection fees by resolution. Such permit and inspection fees shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  The Township may refuse to grant a permit to connect if the Township shall determine the POTW does not have adequate capacity or capability to accommodate the proposed connection. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-198. - Sanitary leads. 
Sanitary leads from all buildings or dwellings shall be privately owned, operated and maintained to the connection point of the public sewer system. Grinder pumps and pressurized sanitary leads shall be owned, operated and maintained by the Township. By utilizing the public sewer system, owners of property utilizing grinder pumps and pressurized sanitary leads shall be deemed to have granted the Township an irrevocable license for the duration of such use for the purpose of entering onto the property serviced so as to operate and maintain the grinder pump and pressurized sanitary leads. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-199. - Separate sanitary leads required; exception waiver. 
A separate and independent sanitary lead shall be provided for each building or premises, and connected to the POTW. The Township may grant a waiver of such requirement, where one building or premises stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building or premises through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the sanitary lead from the front building or premises may be extended to the rear building or premises. The sewer department shall have the sole discretion as to whether a waiver from such requirement is justified. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-200. - Existing sanitary leads. 
An existing sanitary lead may be used in connection with a new building and premises only where it is found, on inspection by the Township, to be of adequate construction, size and location. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-201. - Separation from water lines. 
All sanitary leads shall be laid a minimum of ten feet from any existing and parallel water service lines. All necessary crossovers shall have the water main above the sewer main and at least 18 inches apart, unless otherwise approved by the Township engineers. All sanitary leads and grinder pumps shall meet with minimum isolation distance to water wells as specified in Part 127- Act 368 PA of 1978, as amended or as otherwise approved by the MDEQ or Livingston County Department of Public Health. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-202. - Size, slope and construction specifications. 
The size and slope of the sanitary lead shall be subject to approval by the Township, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-quarter inch per foot, unless otherwise permitted. The slope of the pipe, the diameter of which is six inches or more, shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot, unless otherwise permitted. The sanitary lead shall be constructed of materials as approved by the Township. The Township reserves the right to specify and require the encasement of any sewer pipe with concrete, or the installation of sewer pipe in a concrete cradle, if the foundation and construction are such as to warrant such protection, in the opinion of the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-203. - Elevation. 
Whenever possible, the sanitary lead shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, wastewater carried by such drain shall be lifted by artificial means approved by the Township, and the drain shall discharge to the sanitary lead. No sanitary lead shall be laid parallel to, or within three feet of, any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth of the sanitary lead shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The sanitary lead shall be laid at uniform grade. The line shall be straight or laid with properly curved pipe and fittings. Changes in direction greater than 45 degrees shall be provided with cleanouts accessible for cleaning. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-204. - New construction. 
The basement floor level of all new structures from which it is anticipated that any type of wastewaters may emanate shall be at such level that such wastewaters can flow by gravity to any sanitary sewer or by grinder pump to a pressure collection system. In the alternative, a pump or other suitable device shall be installed and maintained to lift the wastewaters to a level from which they can flow by gravity to such sanitary sewer. An acceptable wastewater outlet facing the street where a sanitary sewer is available, or is proposed to be made available, shall be provided in all new structures. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-205. - Connections. 
Every connection of a sanitary lead into a sanitary sewer shall conform to the requirements of the Township building and plumbing ordinances, as amended, and all other applicable rules and regulations of the Township, the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials and the Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, as amended, as well as, as may be applicable, all requirements of the state, county and/or any governmental agency operating and maintaining public sewers on behalf of the Township. All such connections shall be gastight and watertight. Any deviation from procedures and materials prescribed in this section must be approved in writing by the Township before installation. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-206. - Bonding or insurance for contractors. 
All contractors or owners making connections to the POTW shall be bonded or insured in accordance with the requirements of the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-207. - Extensions on nonresidential properties. 
Where nonresidential property is to be connected to the POTW, and the POTW does not extend the full width of the owner's property, the property owner shall be responsible for extending the POTW, at the owner's cost, across the entire width of such owner's property, so as to allow further extension of the POTW to adjoining properties. In the event of a corner parcel, the property owner shall be responsible for extending the POTW along both the width and length of the property, along both roads upon which the property is located. The size of the sewer shall be determined by the Township engineer. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-208. - Inspection and approval. 
The applicant for a sewer connection permit shall notify the Township when the sanitary lead is ready for installation and connection to the sanitary sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the Township or its authorized representative. No backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected and approved by the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-209. - Barricading and lighting of excavations; restoration of disturbed property. 
(a)  All excavations for sanitary lead installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard per Michigan Occupation Safety and Health Administration 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored to a manner satisfactory to the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-210—34-228. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Use of Public Sewers 
 
Sec. 34-229. - Stormwater and unpolluted drainage. 
No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, to the POTW, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water, unpolluted air conditioning water or uncontaminated industrial process water. No footing drain, sump pump, roof downspout, areaway drain or other source of surface water or groundwater shall be connected to the POTW. All footing drain water shall be discharged to storm sewers or dry wells. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to sewers specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the MDEQ. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-230. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)  No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, to the POTW, any wastewater which contains the substances or possess the characteristics described in subsection (b) of this section; which prevent effective operation of the POTW facilities; which will pass through the POTW treatment plant or be incompatible with or harm the POTW facilities; which are prohibited by any federal or state law, rule, regulation, ordinance, permit requirement or standard which is applicable to the POTW facilities; or which the Township shall have concluded will have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or otherwise endanger the health, safety and welfare of the public or public property, or constitute a nuisance. Before making such determination, the Township shall consider, to the extent appropriate, such factors as the quantities of the subject wastewater in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers; the material with which the sewers are constructed, the nature of the treatment process at the POTW; the capacity of the POTW; the degree of treatability of the wastewaters in the POTW; and other pertinent factors. The Township shall have the option to take action as described herein. 
(b)  A user may not contribute the following substances to the POTW: 
(1)  Any liquids, solids or gases which, by reason of their nature and quantity, are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion, or be injurious in any other way to the POTW or the operation of the POTW. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides. Including waste streams that have a closed cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit or 60 degrees Centigrade using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21 
(2)  Solid or viscous pollutants which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or interfere in the operations of the POTW , such as, but not limited to, grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastics, gas, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining, or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes. 
(3)  Any wastewater having a pH less than 6.5 or greater than 9.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the POTW. 
(4)  Any wastewater containing pollutants that result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes, either alone or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the POTW or exceed the limitation set forth in a categorical pretreatment standard. This prohibition of toxic pollutants will conform to applicable law. 
(5)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases or solids which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair. 
(6)  Any substance which may cause the POTW's effluent or any product of the POTW, such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. 
(7)  Any substance which will cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit or the receiving water quality standards. 
(8)  Any wastewater with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions. 
(9)  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW, resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater with a temperature at the introduction into the POTW which exceeds 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit). 
(10)  Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference to the POTW. 
(11)  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the Township in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(12)  Any wastewater which causes a hazard to human life or creates a public nuisance. 
(13)  Any unpolluted water, including, but not limited to, stormwater, groundwater, roof water or noncontact cooling water. 
(14)  Any wastewater containing suspended solids or any constituent of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such material at the POTW treatment plant. 
(15)  Any sludge, precipitate or congealed substance resulting from an industrial or commercial process, or resulting from the pretreatment of wastewater or air pollutants. 
(16)  Any sodium chloride discharged from a water softener located in a residential, commercial, industrial or other building. 
(17)  Any water or wastewater that exceeds any of the local limits set forth in Discharge Limits of this Ordinance. 
(18)  Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass-through. 
(19)  Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the POTW, but only when trucked or hauled in compliance with the state and federal hazardous waste and liquid industrial waste laws. 
(20)  Any waste or wastewater defined as categorical or subject to a categorical standard. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-231. - Determination of wastewater flow. 
(a)  To determine the wastewater flow from any establishment, the Township may use one of the following methods: 
(1)  The amount of water supplied to the premises by the Township or a private water company, as shown upon the water meter if the premises are metered; 
(2)  If the premises are supplied with river water or water from private wells, the amount of water supplied from such sources, as estimated by the Township from the water, gas or electric supply; 
(3)  If such premises are used for an industrial or commercial purpose of such a nature that the water supplied to the premises cannot be entirely discharged into the sewer system, the estimate of the amount of wastewater discharged into the sewer system, as estimated by the Township from the water, gas or electric supply; 
(4)  The number of gallons of wastewater discharged into the sewer system as determined by measurements and samples taken at a manhole installed by the owner of the property served by the sewer system, at his/her own expense, in accordance with the terms and conditions of the permit issued by the Township; or 
(5)  A figure determined by the Township by any combination of the methods set forth in subsection (c)(1)—(4) of this section or by any other equitable method. 
(b)  Wastewater discharges shall be expressly subject to all provisions of this Division and all other applicable regulations, charges and fees established by the Township. The Township may: 
(1)  Set unit charges or a schedule of user charges and fees for the wastewater to be discharged to the POTW; 
(2)  Limit the average and maximum wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(3)  Limit the average and maximum rate and time of discharge or make requirements for flow regulations and equalization; 
(4)  Require the installation and maintenance of inspection and sampling facilities; 
(5)  Establish specifications for monitoring programs, which may include sampling locations, frequency of sampling, number, types and standards for tests and reporting schedule; 
(6)  Establish compliance schedules; 
(7)  Require submission of technical reports or discharge reports; 
(8)  Require the maintaining, retaining and furnishing of plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the Township and affording Township access thereto and copying thereof; 
(9)  Require notification of the Township for any new introduction of wastewater constituents or any substantial change in the volume or character of the wastewater constituents being introduced into the wastewater treatment system; 
(10)  Require notification of slug discharges; 
(11)  Require other conditions, as deemed appropriate by the Township, to ensure compliance with this division; 
(12)  Require wastewater treatment facilities, process facilities, wastewater streams or other potential wastewater problems to be placed under the specific supervision and control of persons who have been certified by an appropriate state agency as properly qualified to supervise such facilities; 
(13)  Require records and file reports to be maintained on the final disposal of specific liquids, solids, sludges, oils, radioactive materials, solvents or other wastes. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-232. - Discharge limits. 
(a)  All users of the POTW shall maintain discharge limits below the local limits as set forth on the table below. Users shall not be permitted to exceed the local limits. 
TABLE INSET: 
Substance 	Local Limits (mg/l)

Chemical Oxygen Demand 	350

Chromium 	2.41

Lead 	4.09

(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-233. - Dilution. 
No user shall in any way use or increase the use of potable or process water, nor mix separate waste streams, for the purpose of diluting a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the requirements set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-234. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the Township, they are necessary for the proper handling of wastewaters containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients. Notwithstanding the foregoing, interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the Township and shall be located so as to be readily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. Such interceptors shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which, when bolted in place, shall be gastight and watertight. All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained in continuously efficient operation at all times by the owner of the building or premises from which such wastewaters emanate, or his/her authorized representative, at the expense of the owner or his/her authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-235. - Fats, oils, grease (FOG) regulations. 
(a)  Compliance and FOG interceptor permit approval. 
(1)  FOG interceptors to be installed shall be in conformance with the most recent Township POTW policies, the state plumbing code, the Livingston County Sanitary Sewer Codes, and any other applicable federal, state or local regulation. The required interceptor shall be designed according to the most stringent of the above current standards and shall be based upon the aforementioned regulations and the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(2)  In order to obtain approval and be issued a FOG interceptor permit, information must be submitted to the Township regarding: (a) the proposed interceptor location; (b) the proposed size of the FOG interceptor; (c) a detailed drawing of the interceptor and piping; and (d) the number and type of fixtures proposed to be attached. After approval, the facility will be issued a FOG interceptor permit and the FOG interceptor can be installed. Green Oak Township will inspect the FOG interceptor after installation is complete, and the FOG interceptor permit must be kept on file at the subject facility. 
(b)  FOG interceptor regulations. 
(1)  In order to perform correctly, FOG interceptors must be adequately sized. Green Oak Township requires that all FOG interceptors provide a minimum of 12 minutes retention time at theoretical peak flow rate. The following chart can be used to calculate the theoretical peak flow rate based on fixtures connected to the interceptor. 
Peak flow rate values by fixture type 
TABLE INSET: 
Fixture unit 	Peak flow rate (gallons/minute) 
Hand sink 	7.5 
Restaurant kitchen sink 	15 
Single compartment scullery sink 	20 
Double compartment scullery sink 	25 
Triple compartment sink 	30 
Two single compartment sinks 	25 
Two double compartment sinks 	30 
Floor drain 	5 
Dishwasher 	Manufacturer's peak discharge rate 
 
(2)  FOG interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperatures. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which, when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. The interceptor shall contain a baffle system, which adequately diverts and slows the flow to avoid short-circuiting and to ensure cooling of the waste before entering the POTW system to 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Interceptors located in roadways or parking lots should be traffic rated. 
(3)  Each user shall provide protection against the accidental discharge of FOG. Features that prevent accidental discharge of these materials shall be provided and maintained at the user's expense. Information regarding the facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to Green Oak Township for review and approval prior to construction of the facility. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures by Green Oak Township shall not relieve the user of the responsibility to modify its facility as necessary to meet the requirements of this section. 
(4)  All new restaurants and commercial and industrial facilities, which have the potential to discharge FOG into the POTW, shall install a FOG interceptor at a minimum of 750 gallons, or similar FOG removal system, necessary to achieve and maintain compliance with the limit stated herein. 
(5)  Upon six months notification from the Township, or in conjunction with any significant alteration to the structure or use of any existing restaurant or commercial and industrial facility which has the potential to discharge FOG into the POTW system, such restaurant or commercial and industrial facility shall install a FOG interceptor at a minimum of 750 gallons, or similar FOG removal system, necessary to achieve and maintain compliance with the limit stated herein. 
(6)  A restaurant or other commercial or industrial facility that demonstrates that the discharge from its service and/or activities contains less than 100 mg/l of FOG, may receive an exemption from minimum sizing requirements or installation and maintenance requirements. Sampling and testing to demonstrate the concentration of grease in the discharge must be conducted, at the facility's expense, by an independent testing organization and measured in accordance with the analytical test procedures established in 40 CFR 136 as amended from time-to-time. 
(7)  No domestic wastewater or restroom wastewater should enter the FOG interceptor. 
(8)  FOG interceptors shall not be required for single-family homes or multifamily dwelling units, unless problems occur at particular locations more than two times in a 12-month period. 
(9)  All FOG interceptors shall be cleaned on a regular basis by a properly licensed FOG hauler (not a septic hauler), and not less than one time within a three-month period. The necessary frequency of cleaning will vary greatly depending on the nature of the establishment. Factors such as types of food, cooking methods and cleaning techniques will help determine volume of FOG discharged. Facilities with high FOG loadings may have to clean their interceptors as often as monthly. Approved internal or under-counter interceptors shall be cleaned at least once per week, and may be cleaned by in-house staff according to the manufacturers cleaning procedures. In general, FOG interceptors shall be pumped when the FOG concentration exceeds 12 inches in thickness or is within two inches of the discharge pipe in the first chamber. "Jetting out" the FOG removal system is not permitted. Cleaning shall consist of removal of the entire contents of the device, including grease cap and sludge pocket, and inspection of the empty device for defects and/or obstructions which would prevent proper function. 
(10)  All FOG interceptors, or similar FOG removal systems, shall be placed in a location that is readily accessible for cleaning, removal of grease, and acceptable for sampling. The location of the grease interceptor shall meet the approval of the Township for sampling and inspection purposes. The sampling box and manhole shall connect directly to the interceptor prior to any domestic wastewater connections. Sampling stations may be used to monitor the efficiency of any interceptor maintenance program. Upon approval from the Township, the location of each interceptor shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Furthermore, each restaurant or other commercial or industrial facility for which an interceptor is required shall have an interceptor that shall serve only that establishment. 
(11)  The owner of a FOG interceptor irrevocably grants to the Township and its agents the right to enter the subject premises at all reasonable times for the purposes of inspection. The owner, lessee or occupant of any property shall retainany pertinent information regarding cleaning and maintenance of the FOG removal system or the FOG interceptor on-site. The refusal of such information or of access to the property, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of a violation of these provisions. 
(12)  Township sampling and inspections of FOG removal systems that result in noncompliance with these aforementioned standards shall receive written notification that the facility has seven days to pump out the FOG removal system and will be reinspected. If, after reinspection, the FOG removal system is still in noncompliance, the discharger must clean out the FOG removal system immediately. The Township will reinspect the FOG removal system; if the removal system is still in noncompliance, the Township can have the removal system cleaned at the discharger's expense and bill them any associated noncompliance fees. If a discharger's FOG removal system is in noncompliance three times after the initial seven-day reinspection in a consecutive 24-month period, the Township shall take immediate injunctive, equitable or legal action against the discharger. All cost associated with reinspections including testing, injunctive, equitable, and legal fees including attorney fees shall be paid by the property owner. 
(13)  The use of biological or non-biological additives as a FOG degradation, eliminating agent, or an odor control agent is conditionally permissible only upon approval by the Township. Furthermore, if it is determined that the agents being used are not effective or are relocating FOG from the FOG trap to the sewer main or pump station, then the additive shall immediately stop being used and the responsible party shall pay for the necessary maintenance costs to either clean or restore the effected portions of the sewer system as highlighted herein. 
(c)  Recordkeeping. Written records shall be maintained by the user indicating operation, maintenance and cleaning events. Receipts or manifests from FOG haulers should indicate destination of hauled waste. The records shall be made available to the Township inspectors upon request. Maintenance records shall contain: (1) the date of maintenance; (2) the name of the person performing maintenance; (3) the estimated volume of grease removed; (4) the disposal location; and (5) the manager's signature or initials for verification. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-236. - Sampling facilities, structures and equipment. 
When required by the Township to assure adequate monitoring and control of wastewater discharge, the user of any building or premises served by a sanitary lead shall install a suitable sampling structure (e.g., control vault or station) in the sanitary lead prior to connection to the public sanitary sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastewater being discharged. Such sampling structure shall be equipped by the user with a suitable composite sampler and continuous flow recorder. Such sampling structure and equipment shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Township in writing. Such sampling structure shall be installed by the user at his/her cost and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. The person operating and maintaining such sampling facilities shall, at the request of the Township, submit to Township records, or true copies thereof, of the wastewater discharged and such other reports and information as shall be necessary to assess and assure compliance with this Division and the user's discharge permit, if any. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-237—34-266. - Reserved.  
Subdivision IV. - Pretreatment 
 
Sec. 34-267. - Pretreatment standards. 
(a)  All nondomestic users connected to the POTW shall comply with the discharge limits contained in this division. 
(b)  Upon the promulgation of any final federal or state pretreatment standards or discharge limits for a particular industrial category or subcategory, such standards or limits, if more stringent than the requirements set forth in this article, shall: 
(1)  Be automatically incorporated as part of this division; 
(2)  Be considered to supersede the requirements of this article; and 
(3)  Become effective when specified by the promulgating agency. 
(c)  The Township shall notify all affected users of the applicable standards or limits. State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where such requirements and limitations are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this division.
