The Township reserves the right to establish by ordinance more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the wastewater disposal system, if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives of this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-268. - Maintenance of pretreatment facilities. 
Where pretreatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, such facilities shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at no expense to the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-269. - Pretreatment compliance reporting. 
(a)  Compliance data report. Within 30 days following the date for final compliance with an applicable pretreatment standard or discharge limit referenced in this article, or, in the case of a new source of wastewater, following commencement of introduction of the new wastewater into the POTW facilities, any user subject to pretreatment requirements pursuant to this division shall submit to the Township a written report indicating the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated process which are limited by pretreatment standards or discharge limits and the average and maximum daily flow for the process units in the user facility which are limited by such pretreatment standards or discharge limits. The report shall state whether the applicable pretreatment standards or discharge limits are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, what additional operation and maintenance or pretreatment is necessary to bring the user into compliance with the applicable pretreatment standards or discharge limits. The report shall be signed by an authorized representative of the user and certified by a qualified representative. 
(b)  Periodic compliance reports. Any user or new source subject to pretreatment standards or discharge limits shall submit to the Township during the months of June and December, unless required more frequently by the applicable pretreatment standard or discharge limit, or by the Township, a report indicating the nature and concentration of the pollutants in the effluent which are limited by the applicable pretreatment standard or discharge limit. The report shall include all information required in the user's permit but shall include a record of all daily flows. In the discretion of the Township, and after considering such factors as local high or low flow rates, holidays, budget cycles, etc., the Township may alter the months during which the reports are to be submitted. The Township may also impose mass limitations on users which are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases in which the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate. In such cases, the compliance data report required by subsection (a) of this section shall also indicate the mass of pollutants regulated by pretreatment standards in effluent of the user. 
(c)  Progress reports. In instances where a schedule of additional pretreatment and/or implementation of additional operational and maintenance activities has been submitted, not later than 14 days following each milestone date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the Township, including no less than a statement as to whether or not it complied with the increment of progress represented by that milestone date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with the increment of progress, the reason for delay and the steps being taken by the user to return the construction to the schedule. In no event shall more than nine months elapse between such progress reports to the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-270. - Disclosure. 
All industrial users proposing to connect, or contribute wastewater, to the POTW facilities shall submit such information as the Township shall reasonably request regarding their processes and wastewater before connecting, or contributing, to the facilities POTW. All existing industrial users connected, or contributing, to the POTW facilities shall promptly submit such information regarding their processes and wastewater as the Township shall reasonably request. The information submitted shall be sufficient for the Township to determine the impact of the user's discharge on the POTW facilities and the need for a discharge permit and/or pretreatment, and shall be signed by an authorized representative of the user. The user proposing to connect and/or contribute wastewater shall be required to complete the current version of the discharge permit application which has been approved by Township Board Resolution. Without limiting the generality of such disclosure requirements, the information which may be required pursuant to this section may include any or all of the following: 
(a)  Disclosure of the name, address and location of the user, and if not an individual, the names of its owners, shareholders, members, managers, directors, and officers; 
(b)  Disclosure of standard industrial classification (SIC) number according to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Federal Bureau of the Budget, 1972, as amended; 
(c)  Disclosure of wastewater constituents and characteristics, including, but not limited to, those mentioned in this division, as determined by a reliable analytical laboratory. Sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures and methods detailed in the: 
(1)  Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, American Public Health Association, current edition. 
(2)  Manual of Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes, United States Environmental Protection Agency, current edition. 
(3)  Annual Book of Standards, part 131, Water, Atmospheric Analysis, American Society of Testing Materials, current edition. 
(d)  Disclosure of the time and duration of discharges; 
(e)  Disclosure of average daily and instantaneous peak wastewater flow rates, in gallons per day, including daily, monthly and seasonal variations, if any. All flows shall be measured, unless other verifiable techniques are approved by the Township due to cost of non-feasibility; 
(f)  Disclosure of site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans, including noncontact water cooling systems, and details to show all sewers, sewer connections, inspection manholes, sampling chambers and appurtenances, by size, location and elevation; 
(g)  Description of activities, facilities and plant processes on the premises, including all materials which are, or may be, discharged to the POTW facilities; 
(h)  Disclosure of the nature and concentration of any pollutants or materials prohibited by this subdivision in the discharge, together with a statement regarding whether or not compliance is being achieved with this Division, on a consistent basis, and, if not, whether additional operation and maintenance activities and/or additional pretreatment is required for the user to comply with this Division; 
(i)  Disclosure of each product produced, by type, amount or process, and the rate of production; 
(j)  Disclosure of the type and amount of raw materials utilized, average and maximum per day; 
(k)  Any other information required by 40 CFR 403.12, as amended, or any similar successor federal regulation; 
(l)  If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance will be required to meet the pretreatment standards, the shortest schedule by which the user will provide such additional pretreatment. The completion date in the schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. The following conditions shall apply to the schedule: 
(1)  The schedule shall contain increments of progress, in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable pretreatment standard. No increment referred to in this subsection shall exceed nine months. 
(2)  Not later than 14 days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the Township, including, as a minimum, whether or not the user complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which the user expects to comply with the increment of progress, the reason for delay and the steps being taken by the user to return the construction to the schedule established. In no event shall more than nine months elapse between such progress reports to the Township. 
(3)  Within nine months of the promulgation or revision of a National Categorical Pretreatment Standard, all affected users must submit to the Township the information required by subsections (h) and (i) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-271. - Preliminary treatment facilities. 
(a)  Where wastewater is required to be pretreated by the provisions of this division, a user shall provide, at his/her expense, such preliminary treatment as shall be necessary to reduce the objectionable characteristics or constituents of the wastewater, or control the quantities and rates of discharge of the wastewater so that the POTW can operate effectively and in conformance with all federal and/or state laws, rules, regulations, permit requirements, ordinances, or standards which are applicable to the POTW facilities. Plans, specifications and other pertinent information relating to the proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be prepared and submitted by a registered engineer for approval by the Township, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until approval is given by the Township in writing. Review of the submitted plans, specifications and other information shall be completed within a reasonable time. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the Township under the provisions of this division. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported, and acceptable, to the Township prior to the user's initiation of the changes. Where preliminary treatment is required by this division, and the user is already discharging wastewater into the POTW facilities, then the user, at the request of the Township, may agree to a compliance schedule which shall specify, by date, the items which are to be accomplished by the user to complete all necessary preliminary treatment facilities and to bring the wastewater being discharged into compliance with all requirements of this division. 
(b)  Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any wastewater, such facilities shall be operated by an operator licensed by the State of Michigan and continuously maintained in satisfactory and effective operation by the user at his/her cost. The person operating and maintaining such facilities shall, at the request of the Township, submit to the requesting party records or true copies thereof of the samplings taken from wastewater discharged and such other reports and information as shall be necessary to assess and assure compliance with this division and the user's discharge permit, if any. All records relating to compliance with pretreatment standards shall be made available to officials of the EPA or MDEQ, upon request. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-272. - Categorical industrial users prohibited. 
Industrial users that are considered categorical users are prohibited from connecting to and/or discharging to the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-273. - Containment facilities; accidental spills; emergency notification procedure; special agreements. 
(a)  When required by the Township to assure adequate protection of the POTW facilities from accidental spills of critical or hazardous materials, the user shall develop and submit to the Township an adequate spill prevention plan. The adequacy of such plan shall be determined by the Township. The Township may require, as part of such plan, that the user provide, at his/her expense, suitable containment facilities commonly referred to as secondary containment within a time period specified by the Township. Plans, specifications and other pertinent information relating to the proposed containment facilities shall be prepared and submitted for approval by the Township, and no construction of such facilities shall commence until approval by the Township is given in writing. Such containment facilities shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory condition by the user at his/her cost. All required users shall complete such a plan within the required time-frame as specified by the Township. If required by the Township, a user who commences contribution to the POTW after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived shall not be permitted to introduce pollutants into the system until accidental discharge procedures have been approved by the Township. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the industrial user from the responsibility to modify the user's facility, as necessary, to meet the requirements of this division. 
(b)  In the case of an accidental spill, the user shall immediately telephone and notify the Township and the POTW treatment plant of the incident. Such notification shall include the location of the spill, the type of wastewater, concentration and volume, and corrective action. The notice shall be followed up, within five days of the accidental spill, with a detailed written report from the user to the Township describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. The notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss or damage, or other liability which may be incurred as a result of the damage to the POTW facilities or any other damage to person or property resulting from the accidental spill. In addition, such notification shall not relieve the user of any fine, civil penalty or other liability which may be imposed pursuant to this article or other applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation. 
(c)  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees of whom to call in the event of a dangerous discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who may cause or suffer such a dangerous discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(d)  No statement contained in this Section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the Township and any person whereby wastewater of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the Township, subject to payment by the person, provided such wastewater will not damage the sanitary sewer, storm sewer, POTW treatment plant or receiving waters. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-274. - Annual publications. 
The Township shall annually publish in the Township paper of record or on the Township website: 
(a)  a list of the users which were significantly violating any National Categorical Pretreatment Standard promulgated by the EPA during the 12 previous months. The notification shall also summarize any enforcement actions taken against those users during the same 12-month period. 
(b)  a list of all industrial users which were the subject of enforcement proceedings pursuant to this division during the 12 previous months for significant noncompliance that remained uncorrected for a period of 45 or more days after notification of noncompliance, or which have exhibited a pattern of noncompliance over that 12-month period, or which involve failure to accurately report noncompliance. The list shall provide a summary of the enforcement action taken against each such user listed. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Subdivision V. - Discharge Permits 
 
Sec. 34-275. - When required. 
The Township may, at its discretion, require that an existing industrial user or other nondomestic user procure and maintain in effect a discharge permit, issued by the Township, as a condition precedent to making any discharge to the POTW facilities. The Township may require an existing or potential industrial or other nondomestic user to obtain a discharge permit whenever it shall reasonably determine that the user's discharge or potential discharge may adversely impact the POTW facilities or if the user's discharges do not or may not comply with the local limits or other provisions in this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-276. - Application. 
Every existing or potential user required to procure a discharge permit pursuant to this subdivision shall make application for such permit in the form and manner prescribed by the Township. The application shall include all facts and information necessary for the Township to reasonably consider and evaluate the granting or denial of the discharge permit application. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-277. - Approval or denial. 
Upon receipt of a completed permit application, the Township shall, within a reasonable time, grant or deny the requested discharge permit. During the pendency of an application, an existing user may continue to discharge to the POTW facilities subject, however, to compliance with this division and all other applicable provisions of local, state or federal law. A discharge permit may be granted with such conditions and restrictions as the Township shall reasonably determine to be necessary or appropriate to achieve compliance with this division. The conditions and restrictions may be amended from time-to-time during the term of the permit, on 30 days' written notice to the permit holder, as the Township shall determine to be reasonably necessary or appropriate to comply with all applicable provisions of this article, local, state or federal law, or as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate for the POTW treatment plant to which the permittee is a contributor to meet the requirements of all permits applicable to its operation. A violation of any condition or restriction in a user's discharge permit shall be deemed a violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-278. - Fee. 
The Township shall establish by resolution the fee to be paid to the Township for a discharge permit application, review and permit. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-279. - Expiration and renewal. 
All discharge permits issued by the Township shall be valid for five years from the date issued unless otherwise specified in the permit. An application for renewal of a permit shall be considered in the same manner as an original application. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-280. - Transferability. 
No permit shall be transferred to a different user or premises, or to a new or changed operation, without the prior written consent of the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-281. - Denial, suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A discharge permit may be revoked or suspended by the Township at any time for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or any material false statement in the application for the permit; 
(2)  Any violation of the conditions and restrictions included as part of the permit; or 
(3)  Any violation of this division or this article. 
(b)  Written notice of suspension or revocation, stating the cause therefore, shall be delivered to the permit holder personally or mailed by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the permit holder's address as shown in the application for the permit. 
(c)  Any user whose permit is revoked or suspended, any user or potential user whose application for a permit is denied or any user or potential user whose permit is conditioned or restricted in a manner which is unacceptable to the applicant shall have the right to a hearing before the Township Board, provided, a written request for such hearing is filed with the Township within 15 days following the delivery or mailing of the notice of revocation or suspension, or within 15 days following the denial of the application for a permit or the granting of a permit with unacceptable conditions or restrictions. 
(d)  Following receipt of a written request for a such a hearing, the Township Board shall fix a reasonable date and time for the hearing of the request. 
(e)  Following a hearing, the Township Board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the challenged action and impose conditions or restrictions, and it may direct that a permit be reinstated, issued or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-282. - Delegation. 
The Township Board may, by resolution, which shall be amendable and revocable at any time, delegate all or any part of the permit functions and responsibilities specified in this subdivision to the POTW industrial surveillance personnel. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-283—34-302. - Reserved.  
DIVISION III. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL  
Subdivision I. - Private Sewage Disposal 
 
Sec. 34-303. - Use of private sewage disposal system. 
If a house, building or other premises used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes is not connected to a sanitary sewer, then the sanitary lead shall be connected to private sewage disposal facilities permitted and approved by the health department and, where appropriate, the MDEQ and the Township, and constructed in accordance to the current adopted standards of the MDEQ and Livingston County. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-304. - Prohibited private sewage disposal systems. 
No new private sewage disposal system shall be constructed utilizing an open lagoon system, cesspool, or a spray irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-305. - As-built drawings. 
Electronic files (signed and sealed PDF plans and copies in either ESRI format for shapefile), signed and sealed by a professional engineer of the as-built certification for the private sewage disposal system will be submitted by the applicant or his/her engineer to the Township building department upon completion of system construction. This information will be coordinated with issuance of building permits for construction of the other elements of the project, based on the approved phases. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-306. - Disconnection and abandonment of facilities. 
At such time as a connection is made to a sanitary sewer, all private sewage disposal facilities shall be disconnected and abandoned. All abandoned private sewage disposal systems shall be closed in accordance with the Township, County and/or MDEQ standards and procedures. The property owner shall file proof of abandonment with the Township within 30 days of the abandonment. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-307. - Operation and maintenance of facilities. 
All persons owning or maintaining private sewage disposal facilities shall operate and maintain such facilities in a safe and sanitary manner and in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, without the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. All costs associated with the operation, maintenance and replacement of a private sewage disposal system shall be borne by the property owners served by such systems and at no cost to the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-308. - Additional requirements. 
The provisions of this subdivision shall not be construed to preclude additional requirements that may be imposed by the MDEQ, the health department, or the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-309—34-328. - Reserved.  
DIVISION IV. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES  
Subdivision I. - Regulations. 
 
Sec. 34-329. - Violation of regulations. 
A violation of the regulations detailed in all divisions of this article shall be deemed to be a municipal civil infraction unless otherwise specified. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-330. - Fines. 
(a)  The following civil fines shall apply in the event of a determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction, unless a different fine and/or penalty is otherwise specified: 
(1)  The civil fine for a first offense violation shall be in an amount of $250.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each offense. 
(2)  The civil fine for any second offense shall be in an amount of $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each offense. 
(3)  The civil fine for any third offense shall be in the amount of $750.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each offense. 
(4)  The civil fine for any fourth and subsequent offense shall be in the amount of $1,000.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each offense. 
(b)  In addition to ordering a person to pay the municipal civil infractions set forth above, other equitable or legal remedies, civil fines, costs, damages, attorney fees and expenses may also be pursued or assessed, and any judgment, writ or order necessary to enforce or enjoin violation of this article shall be executed. Any person found in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be liable to the Township for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the Township by reason of such violation. Said person shall also be liable for repairing or restoring any sanitary sewer, storm sewer, and natural outlet damaged, obstructed, or impaired by such violation to its pre-existing condition. 
(c)  Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-331. - Recover of costs. 
Any user violating any of the provisions of this article or who causes a discharge producing a deposit or obstruction, or causes damage to, or impairs, the POTW facilities, shall be liable to the Township for any expense, loss or damage caused by such violation or discharge. The Township may bill the user for the costs incurred by the Township for any cleaning, repair or replacement work caused by the violation or discharge. Refusal to pay such billed costs shall constitute a violation of this article, enforceable as provided in this division and by appropriate legal action. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-332—34-351. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Administrative Remedies 
 
Sec. 34-352. - Administrative remedies. 
(a)  The Township may suspend sanitary sewer wastewater treatment services to any user when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of the Township, in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge that presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or the environment, causes or may cause pass through or interference to the POTW, or causes or may cause the POTW to violate any condition of its groundwater discharge or NPDES permit. The Township may also suspend, revoke, or terminate the wastewater discharge permit of any user that: 
(1)  Fails to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(2)  Fails to report significant changes in wastewater constituents or characteristics; 
(3)  Refuses reasonable access to the user's premises by representatives of the Township for the purpose of inspection or surveillance; or 
(4)  Violates any conditions of its wastewater discharge permit, this Article, or administrative order issued hereunder. 
(b)  Administrative notices and orders. 
(1)  Notice of violation. When it is determined that a user has violated any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, the Township may issue a notice of violation to formally document the noncompliance. This document will specify the nature of the violation, establish a date by which the violation shall be corrected, and notify the affected user that failure to correct the violation will constitute a further violation that may result in additional enforcement action. The notice of violation shall be sent via first-class mail or personally served on an authorized representative of the industrial user. Receipt, or non-receipt, of a notice of violation shall in no way relieve the affected user of any and all liability associated with the violation. Issuance of a notice of violation shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(2)  Order to show cause. When it is determined that a user has violated any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, the Township may issue an administrative order to show cause to require the affected user to appear at a hearing to demonstrate why escalated enforcement action should not be pursued. This document shall specify the nature of the violation, establish the time and place for the hearing, and notify the affected user that failure to comply would constitute a further violation of this article that may result in additional enforcement action. The order to show cause shall be issued at least ten days prior to the hearing, and shall be sent via certified mail/return receipt requested or personally served on an authorized representative of the industrial user. Receipt, or non-receipt, of an order to show cause shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of an order to show cause or conducting of the show cause hearing shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(3)  Order of consent. When the Township and an affected user agree to a violation and to the remedial solution, the Township may issue an order of consent to formally establish such agreement. The order of consent shall specify the nature of the violation and required actions such as compliance schedules, stipulated fines, additional self-monitoring, and improvements to treatment facilities or management practices designed to control the user's discharge to the sewer. The order of consent shall be sent via certified mail/return receipt requested or personally served on an authorized representative of the industrial user, and shall require signatures of representatives from both the Township and the affected user. The order of consent shall have the same force and effect as other administrative orders issued by the Township pursuant to this article, shall be judicially enforceable, and shall not modify the requirements or extend the deadline for compliance established by a pretreatment standard or requirement. Receipt, or non-receipt, of an order of consent shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of an order of consent shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(4)  Order to achieve compliance. When the Township and affected user do not agree to the violation or to the remedial solution, the Township may issue an order to achieve compliance. The order to achieve compliance shall specify the nature of the violation and establish required actions such as compliance schedules, stipulated fines, additional self-monitoring, and improvements to treatment facilities or management practices designed to control the user's discharge to the sewer. The order to achieve compliance shall be issued unilaterally in that terms need not be agreed to by the affected user, and shall be sent via certified mail/return receipt requested or personally served on an authorized representative of the industrial user. The order to achieve compliance shall have the same force and effect as other administrative orders issued by the Township pursuant to this article, shall be judicially enforceable, and shall not modify the requirements or extend the deadline for compliance established by a pretreatment standard or requirement. Receipt, or non-receipt, of an order to achieve compliance shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of an order to achieve compliance shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(5)  Cease and desist order. When it is determined that a user has violated and continues to violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, the Township may issue a cease and desist order requiring the affected user to eliminate the violation within 24 hours or face suspension of sewer service. This document shall specify the nature of the violation and require that the violation cease. If the violation has not been corrected within the ordered time period, the Township may suspend sewer service without further notice until such time as the affected user is able to demonstrate that it can comply with discharge standards and requirements. The cease and desist order shall be personally served on an authorized representative of the industrial user. Receipt, or non-receipt, of a cease and desist order shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of a cease and desist order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(6)  Emergency cease and desist order/suspension of service. Whenever it is determined that a user has violated any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, and that the violation creates or threatens to create an emergency situation including but not limited to pass-through or interference at the POTW, damage to the POTW, hazard to the environment, endangerment to the public health and safety, or violation of any condition of the Township's NPDES permit, the Township may issue an emergency cease and desist order. The emergency cease and desist order shall specify the nature of the violation, notify the affected user to eliminate the violating discharge immediately or face service severance via a temporary plug in its sewer connection at any time and without further warning, require that the user not recommence discharges until such time as the affected user is able to demonstrate that it can comply with the discharge requirements, and notify the affected user of its liability for any costs incurred by the Township to conduct this enforcement action. This document shall also establish the time and place for a hearing where the affected user shall present a written statement regarding the causes of the violation and measures taken to prevent future occurrences. The emergency cease and desist order will be personally served to an authorized representative of the industrial user, or may be delivered verbally via telephone to an authorized representative of the industrial user and then served personally. Receipt, or non-receipt, of an emergency cease and desist order shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of an emergency cease and desist order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(7)  Notice of termination. Except for emergency situations covered under this subdivision, whenever it is determined that a user's continuing violation of any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement warrants revocation of its privilege to discharge to the POTW, the Township may issue a notice of termination to warn of the impending suspension of the sewer service up to and including suspension severance via temporary plug in the affected user's sewer connection. The notice of termination shall specify the date and the time of scheduled service suspension in order to allow the affected user to either voluntarily cease the violating discharge or arrange appropriate actions such as production shut-down or alternative means of wastewater disposal, and notify the affected user of its liability for any costs incurred by the Township to conduct this enforcement action. This document shall also establish the time and place for a hearing where the affected user shall present a written statement regarding the causes of the violation and measures taken to prevent future occurrences. The notice of termination will be personally served on the user at least ten days before the scheduled service suspension. Receipt, or non-receipt, of a notice of termination shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of a notice of termination shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(8)  Liable for fines, penalties, costs. In addition to the prescribed herein, the affected user shall be liable for all fines, penalties, and associated legal and other costs incurred by the Township as the result of a violation of its groundwater discharge or NPDES discharge permit that is attributable, in whole or in part, to the user's violation of any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(9)  When the Township finds that a user has violated or continues to violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, an administrative fine may be assessed against the affected user in an amount up to $500.00 per violation. Administrative fines may be assessed in addition to municipal civil infraction fines. Each day during which the violation occurred or continues to occur may be deemed a separate violation and, in the case of a violation of monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, each day during the period of averaging may be deemed a separate violation. Receipt, or non-receipt, of an administrative fine shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. Issuance of an administrative fine shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other enforcement actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(10)  Except for emergency situations covered under this subdivision, any user desiring to dispute a Township-issued notice of violation or order, including but not limited to fines, may present a formal request for reconsideration. Such a request shall be submitted in writing to the Township to the attention of the Township Clerk and the Township Supervisor within ten days of first being notified of the corresponding order for all but a notice of termination, where such a request shall be submitted within five days of notification. Following receipt of a request for reconsideration, the Township Board shall fix a reasonable date and time for Board consideration of the request. Following consideration of the request, the Township Board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the challenged notice of violation, order, and/or fine and/or impose other conditions or restrictions. Submittal of a request for reconsideration shall not stay the corresponding limit, notice of violation, order, fine, or any other enforcement proceedings by the Township against the affected user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-353. - Public nuisance declared. 
Any violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance per se. Accordingly, the court shall, by injunction, order such nuisance abated and the user shall be adjudged guilty of maintaining a nuisance per se. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-354—34-373. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Judicial Remedies 
 
Sec. 34-374. - Injunctive relief. 
(a)  When it is determined that a user has violated or continues to violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, the Township may petition the Circuit Court of Livingston County or other court of competent jurisdiction for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief. 
(b)  A user who has violated or continues to violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, shall be liable to issuance of a preliminary injunction or a permanent injunction or both as may be appropriate. This action shall be sought to restrain or compel activities on the part of the affected user. A petition for injunctive relief shall in no way relieve the affected user of any liability associated with the violation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-375. - Civil penalties. 
(a)  A user who has violated or continues to violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, shall be liable for a civil penalty of up to $1,000.00 per violation as provided supra. Civil penalties may be sought and awarded in addition municipal civil infraction fines and administrative fines. Each day during which the violation occurred or continues to occur may be deemed a separate distinct violation and, in the case of a violation of monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, each day during the period of averaging may be deemed a separate violation. The affected user will also be liable for any and all costs incurred by the Township for associated enforcement action such as reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, additional sampling and monitoring expenses, costs of any environmental damage, any fines imposed upon the Township for groundwater discharge permit or NPDES permit violations that result, in whole or in part, from the user's violation, as well as expenses associated with remediation of sites thereby affected or contaminated. The Township may petition the court to impose, assess, and recover sums up to this limit of liability. 
(b)  In determining the appropriate amount of civil penalty to seek, the Township may take into account all relevant circumstances, including but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained by the affected user as a result of the violation, corrective actions implemented or proposed to be implemented by the affected user, and history of compliance or noncompliance by the affected user. 
(c)  A suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-376. - Criminal prosecution. 
(a)  A user who has willfully or negligently violated or continues to willfully or negligently violate any provision of its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement, shall be liable to criminal prosecution. If convicted, the affected user will be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be punished by a monetary penalty of up to $500.00 per violation, imprisonment for up to 90 days, or both. Each day during which the violation occurred or continues to occur may be deemed a separate distinct violation and, in the case of a violation of monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, each day during the period of averaging may be deemed a separate violation. Criminal prosecution will not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(b)  Falsifying information. A user who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certifications in any application, report, record, plan, or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement shall be liable to criminal prosecution. If convicted, the affected user shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be punished by a monetary penalty of up to $500.00 per violation, imprisonment for up to 90 days, or both. Each day during which the violation occurred or continues to occur may be deemed a separate distinct violation and, in the case of a violation of monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, each day during the period of averaging may be deemed a separate violation. 
(c)  Tampering. A user who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any data device or test method used to monitor a discharge pursuant to this its wastewater discharge permit, this article, administrative order issued hereunder, or other pretreatment standard or requirement will be liable to criminal prosecution. If convicted, the affected user shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be punished by a monetary penalty of up to $500.00 per violation, imprisonment for up to 90 days, or both. Each day during which the violation occurred or continues to occur may be deemed a separate distinct violation and, in the case of a violation of monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, each day during the period of averaging may be deemed a separate violation. 
(d)  A criminal prosecution shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, any other actions by the Township against the affected user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Secs. 34-377—34-396. - Reserved.  
DIVISION V. - MISCELLANEOUS 
 
Sec. 34-397. - Administrative liability. 
No officer, agent or employee of the Township or its authorized representative or member of the Township Board shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to any person as a result of any act, decision or other consequence or occurrence arising out of the discharge of their duties and responsibilities pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-398. - Rules and regulations. 
The Township may from time-to-time by resolution adopt rules and regulations governing operational, maintenance and technical matters relating to the POTW. Violation of any such rule or regulation shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-399. - Authority to inspect. 
The Township and its employees and agents, when bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted, with or without advance notice, to enter in and upon buildings and premises as may be necessary for the purpose of inspection, surveillance, measurement, sampling and testing to determine compliance with this article. Any person who has applied for, and is receiving, sewer service shall be deemed to have consented to the inspection authorized by this section. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-400. - Injury to facilities. 
No person shall enter or maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, equipment or other part of the POTW. Cost associated with damage to POTW, including repair costs, labor, materials, of the Township by unauthorized alteration shall be invoiced and or assessed to the property owner including court cost and attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-401. - Unauthorized use or alteration. 
No person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb the POTW, or appurtenance thereto, without first obtaining a written permit, which specifically allows such alteration, from the Township. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-402. - Delegation of authority. 
The Township Board may, by resolution that shall be amendable and revocable at any time, delegate all or any part of the permit, inspection and other Township functions or responsibilities specified in this subdivision to any other governmental or private agency operating and maintaining public sewers on behalf of the Township. Such resolution shall be effective only for such portion of the Township public sewers as are operated and maintained by such agency. Regardless of any delegation authorized by this section, the Township Board only shall have the authority to refuse a permit to connect as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-403. - Delegation. 
The Township Board may, by resolution, which shall be amendable and revocable at any time, delegate all or any part of the functions, responsibilities and enforcement duties specified in this subdivision to the POTW treatment plant industrial surveillance personnel and/or any other governmental or private agency operating and maintaining public sewers on behalf of the Township. Such delegation may be exclusive or, alternatively, on a coequal basis between the Township and the POTW treatment plant industrial surveillance personnel and/or any other governmental or private agency. However, the establishment of any industrial surveillance fee or cost reimbursement to be charged, all surcharges, and all cost recovery shall be within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Township Board. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-404. - Measurements, tests and analyses. 
All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of wastewater to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Sewage, a joint publication of the American Public Health Association, the American Waterworks Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation, or similar successor publication. All analytical and sampling procedures and methods shall meet the requirements in 40 CFR Part 136). All determinations shall be made based on samples taken at a control vault or station. If no vault or station has been required, then such determination shall be made at the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer from the point at which the sanitary lead is connected to the public sewer. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-405. - Industrial surveillance. 
(a)  With respect to all users that are required to maintain preliminary treatment facilities or sampling facilities pursuant to this article, the Township shall institute a program pursuant to which Township personnel periodically check and assess, through samplings, the accuracy and completeness of the sampling records and other reports and information provided to the Township by the user pursuant to this article. The cost and expense incurred by the Township in conducting the program of periodic review shall be based on actual costs to implement industrial surveillance for each sewer customer or class of sewer customers to which the fee applies and shall be billed by the Township as part of each affected sewer customer's periodic sewer billing. 
(b)  If, based upon such review, the Township determines that the sampling records or other reports and information provided pursuant to this Ordinance are not substantially accurate, the Township may institute such sampling, laboratory analysis and other procedures, as necessary, to accurately sample and measure the wastewater being discharged. All expenses and charges incurred by the Township for such sampling, review and analysis shall be charged to the affected sewer customer. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-406. - Confidential information. 
(a)  Information and data concerning a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits, monitoring programs and inspections shall be available to the public and other governmental agencies, without restriction, unless the user specifically requests that such information and data not be divulged because it is information, processes or methods of production which are entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. 
(b)  When requested by the person furnishing a report, the portion of a report which might disclose trade secrets shall not, to the extent permitted by law, be made available for inspection by the public, but shall be made available upon written request to governmental agencies for uses related to this division and the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit for the POTW treatment plant; provided, however, that such portions of a report shall be available for use by the state or any state agency in judicial review or enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics shall not be considered as confidential information. 
(c)  To the extent permitted by law, information accepted by the Township as confidential shall not be transmitted to any governmental agency or the general public by the Township unless authorized by the user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-407. - Records retention. 
Any user subject to reporting requirements imposed under this article shall maintain records of all information resulting from all sampling activities. Such records shall include the date, exact place, method and time of sampling, the names of the persons taking the samples, the dates the analyses were performed, who performed the analyses, the analytical technique/method used for the analyses and the results of such analyses. Such records shall be maintained for a minimum of five years from the date on which the samplings took place. Such records shall be made available for inspection at the request of the Township. The period of retention shall be extended during the course of any litigation between the Township and the user. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-408. - Operating upsets. 
(a)  Any user which experiences an upset in operations, which places the user in a temporary state of noncompliance with this division, shall immediately telephone and notify the Township and the POTW treatment plant to which he is a contributor. A written follow up report thereof shall be filed by the user with the Township and the POTW treatment plant within five days. The report shall specify the following: 
(1)  Description of the upset, the cause thereof and the upset's impact on the user's compliance status. 
(2)  Duration of noncompliance, including exact dates and times of noncompliance and, if the noncompliance continues, the time by which compliance is reasonably expected to occur. 
(3)  All steps taken, or to be taken, to reduce, eliminate and prevent recurrence of such an upset or other conditions of noncompliance. 
(b)  A documented and verified bona fide operating upset shall be in affirmative defense to any enforcement action brought by the Township against a user for any noncompliance with this division which arises out of violations alleged to have occurred during the period of the upset. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
Sec. 34-409. - Conflicts. 
Where provisions of any state law, rule or regulation, or other Township ordinance impose greater restrictions or higher standards than contained in this division, then the provisions of such law, rule, regulation or other Township ordinance shall control. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 2, eff. 3-15-2013)  
DIVISION VI. - COMMUNITY WASTEWATER UTILITY SYSTEMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-2015, § 1, effective July 26, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 34-417—34-424. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Div. VI, §§ 34-410—34-410.7. 
 
Sec. 34-410. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  Pursuant to Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended, the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality ("MDEQ") is authorized to issue permits for on-site sewage disposal systems that service more than one property (referred to herein as a "community wastewater utility system"). The Township recognizes that a community wastewater utility system may be in the best interests of the health, safety, and welfare of the Township and the residents in some very limited circumstances. However, the Township requires assurance that, any community wastewater utility system will be designed, constructed, operated, maintained, repaired and/or replaced in a manner that best serves and protects the health, safety, and welfare of the Township and its residents. Furthermore, the Township requires that it shall be indemnified by the owner and operator of the community wastewater system from any costs or liability in connection with the design, construction, operation, maintenance, repair and/or replacement of that system. 
(b)  The Township also recognizes that, should the operation of a community wastewater system fail or otherwise not properly function or if the owner or operator of the community wastewater utility system fails or is unable to continue to operate the system, the Township may be required to take over the operation of the community wastewater utility system in order to protect the health, welfare, and safety of residents of the Township. To this effect, this division is intended to regulate community wastewater utility systems to provide those assurances, including the authority of the Township to defray any costs of repairing/maintaining the system by establishing a special assessment district against any property benefited by the community wastewater utility system in accordance with the provisions of Act 188 of Public Acts of 1954, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 04-2015, § 1, eff. 7-26-2015)  
Sec. 34-410.1. - Authority. 
This article is enacted under the authority of the Township's general police powers to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its residents and under the authority of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 04-2015, § 1, eff. 7-26-2015)  
Sec. 34-410.2. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them below: 
(a)  Act 451 means Act. No. 451 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1994, as amended. 
(b)  Association , for a condominium development, shall have the same meaning as "association of co-owners" found in Act No. 59 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1978, as amended. For a subdivision or other development, it shall mean an association of homeowners or property owners organized pursuant to deed restrictions and/or restrictive covenants or through their own volition in a particular development. 
(c)  Community wastewater utility system , system and CWUS are used synonymously in this chapter and mean a facility that is owned by a non-governmental entity and is designed, constructed, operated, and maintained to transport, collect, process, and treat sanitary sewage from more than one structure or from more than one parcel of property. 
(d)  CWUS operator means a legal entity of perpetual duration that is responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the community wastewater utility system. 
(e)  CWUS owner means the single non-governmental entity that owns and controls, or is proposed to own and control, the CWUS facilities. 
(f)  Development means and includes a subdivision as defined by Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of 1967, as amended, a condominium pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 59 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended, and applicable Township ordinance or any group of dwellings, buildings or structures on one or more parcels of land that are proposed to be serviced by a community wastewater utility system. 
(g)  Development documents means: 
(1)  For a condominium project, the master deed and bylaws provided by Act No. 59 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended; 
(2)  With regard to subdivisions or other developments, deed restrictions and/or restrictive covenants, including deed restrictions required by this article; and 
(3)  The articles of incorporation and bylaws of the association. 
(h)  Expansion means any activity whereby additional structures or users shall be added to an existing system. 
(i)  Public sanitary sewer system means a publicly-owned sanitary sewer system. 
(j)  MDEQ means the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality, and its successors. 
(k)  Owner means the owner of property which is serviced or is proposed to be serviced by a community wastewater utility system. Ownership may include fee simple interest, land contract purchase, or other form of ownership of a unit in a condominium, a lot in a subdivision, or a parcel of land in other types of developments. 
(Ord. No. 04-2015, § 1, eff. 7-26-2015)  
Sec. 34-410.3. - Regulations. 
(a)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct, install, or operate a community wastewater utility system within the Township. 
(b)  Community wastewater utility systems shall require a special use permit from the planning commission in accordance with the procedures and standards set forth in section 38-44, special approval use of the Zoning Ordinance. A community wastewater utility system shall be designed, constructed and operated solely for the development it is intended to serve, but may be approved with additional capacity to serve future or additional properties. 
(c)  No new community wastewater utility system or an expansion of an existing system shall be constructed, installed, or operated within the Township unless the Township Board has issued a permit approving the plans for the design, construction, installation, maintenance and operation of the system pursuant to this chapter. The Township Board shall review an application for a permit under this Chapter after a special approval use permit has been conditionally approved and may approve the permit application only after the Township Board determines that the applicant has met all the standards and requirements for approval contained in this chapter. 
(d)  There shall at all times be a single entity that owns and controls the CWUS facility, who is the CWUS owner. The CWUS owner shall be the owner and developer of the development, subject only to a transfer of ownership and control to an association or other third party that has been approved by the Township Board based on financial ability and viability and a vested interest in the proper operation and maintenance of the system. 
(e)  In addition to complying with this chapter, community wastewater utility systems must comply with all other sections of this code applicable to the design, construction and installation of sewer and wastewater systems for developments in the Township. 
(Ord. No. 04-2015, § 1, eff. 7-26-2015)  
Sec. 34-410.4. - Standards and specifications; requirements for approval. 
(a)  The design, construction, and operation of the proposed community wastewater utility system shall comply with the terms of this chapter, other applicable sections of this Code, and the applicable laws. 
(b)  No permit for a new community wastewater utility system or an expansion of an existing system shall be approved unless the plans for the design, construction, installation and operation of the system have been approved by all governmental authorities having jurisdiction over the construction and maintenance of community wastewater utility systems, including but not limited to the state department of public health, the MDEQ, and the state public service commission. 
(c)  The applicant shall provide the following to the Township before approval of a permit for a community wastewater utility system may be granted: 
(1)  The plans for the design, construction, installation and operation of the system. 
(2)  The proposed specifications, standards and guidelines for operation, inspection, monitoring, maintenance, repair and replacement of the system. 
(3)  An original signed written certification from the system design engineer, including the identification of the engineer's professional seal and license number accompanied by an unconditional statement certifying that the system as designed and constructed will adequately process wastewater as required by applicable laws and regulations of the state, the county and the Township. The Township engineer shall review and make a recommendation regarding the adequacy of such certification. 
(4)  An executed agreement between the CWUS owner and the applicable department of the county or another properly certified CWUS operator possessing the required ability to operate and manage the system. The agreement shall contain provisions for: 
a.  The operation, monitoring, inspection, maintenance, repair, and replacement of the system, as designed and approved; 
b.  The collection of charges for connection to, and use, operation, maintenance, repair, and replacement of the system; 
c.  Compliance with all applicable governmental laws, ordinances, regulations, and agreements regarding the system; 
(5)  At the time of application, the applicant shall establish an escrow account for the purposes of paying the costs of all building, engineering, and legal reviews incurred in reviewing all required information and documentation with respect to the application. 
(6)  Any other provisions deemed necessary by the Township to ensure consistency and compliance with this article and the development agreement described in section 34-421(e) below. The agreement shall reference this chapter and any permit that may be issued hereunder, and it shall provide that it may not be terminated without advance written notice to the Township and approval by the Township of a suitable substitute as a condition of continuing compliance with this chapter, and that the agreement shall not be amended without the advance written consent of the Township and any amendments without such consent shall be invalid and of no force or effect. The Township attorney and Township engineer shall review and make recommendations regarding the adequacy of such an agreement and any amendments thereto. 
a.  An executed development agreement between the CWUS owner and the Township in a form acceptable to the Township. At a minimum, the agreement shall: 
1.  Provide that the CWUS owner is responsible for operation, monitoring, inspection, maintenance, repair and replacement of the system. 
2.  Identify the CWUS operator who is responsible for such operation, maintenance, monitoring, inspection, repair and replacement on behalf of the CWUS owner. 
3.  Specify minimum standards for inspection, monitoring, operation, maintenance, repair and replacement of the system in accordance with the specifications, standards and guidelines recommended by the system manufacturer, system design engineer and the certified CWUS operator, and the requirements of the Township, state and the county. 
4.  State the CWUS's agreement to indemnify and hold harmless the Township and its officers, employees, agents, representatives and contractors from any and all damages, injuries, liability, claims, actions, losses, demands and/or law suits, including attorney fees and costs that in any way arise out of or relate to the community wastewater treatment utility system, including but not limited to the operation, inspection, monitoring, maintenance, repair and replacement of the system and the failure to do so. 
5.  Require the CWUS owner to provide and maintain at all times a policy of insurance, including casualty insurance for the replacement value of the insurable components of the system, comprehensive general liability insurance, sewage back-up, overflow and flooding liability insurance, and pollution legal liability insurance with limits acceptable to the Township. The Township and its officers, employees, agents, contractors and representatives shall be named as additional insureds on the insurance policies. All insurance policies shall be issued by an insurer registered/licensed in the state and with an A.M. Best Rating acceptable to the Township. No policy of such insurance shall be cancelled or permitted to lapse without 30 days advance written notice to the Township and without securing similar coverage. 
6.  Grant the Township the right and authority that may be exercised at its sole discretion, to require that the community sewer system be abandoned and all properties in the development be connected to any publicly-owned community sewer system that is constructed and available in the future to serve the development, and obligate the CWUS owner, at its expense, to comply with such requirements if exercised by the Township. 
7.  Include a provision agreeing that the Township shall have the option, but not the obligation, to purchase for the sum of $1.00: 
i.  Marketable title to any lands required to be titled in the name of the Township by governmental or regulatory requirements; or 
ii.  Easements reasonably deemed by the Township to be necessary, required in the event the Township assumes responsibility for the community wastewater utility system or any future publicly-owned community sewer system. 
8.  The development agreement shall include a provision that the applicant and owner has agreed to the establishment of a special assessment district for the development, without further notice, the purpose of which shall be to provide for the assessment of the units, lots or parcels in each development by the Township for the costs of inspection, monitoring, maintenance, repair, operation or replacement of the community wastewater utility system in the event the CWUS owner shall fail to properly perform such work or in the event the Township takes control of the community wastewater utility system. Said special assessment district may be established by agreement with the Township. After approval, the development agreement shall be recorded against the subject property, with the cost for recording paid by the applicant. 
9.  Grant the Township the right, but not the obligation, to take over ownership and operation of the CWUS in the event that the CWUS owner: 
i.  Becomes insolvent or goes into bankruptcy or receivership; 
ii.  Fails to maintain the required operating, maintenance, and capital reserves required by this chapter within six months after written notice from the Township that the reserves do not meet the requirements of this chapter; or 
iii.  Is unable, unwilling or fails for any reason to operate, maintain, inspect, monitor, repair or replace the CWUS, or any part thereof, in full compliance with this article where failure to meet such requirements in six successive months or in more than eight months in a 12-month period shall be conclusively determined to be an inability to comply with. In the event that the Township assumes ownership of the CWUS, the Township shall hold and operate the CWUS for the benefit of the association and owners. The Township may transfer the facilities, assets, and reserves of the CWUS to a new CWUS owner on the condition that such facilities, assets, or reserves be used solely for providing sewer services to the owners, in compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
10.  Provide that, in the event the Township takes over ownership and operation of the CWUS, the costs and expenses incurred by the Township in doing so, plus an administrative fee in an amount no less than 25 percent of such costs and expenses, shall constitute a debt that shall be paid to the Township from the following sources: from the funds in the system maintenance and replacement funds required under this chapter; if the foregoing funding sources are insufficient or unavailable for any reason, then from the proceeds of assessments to the properties within the special assessment district established pursuant to this chapter; and if the foregoing funding sources are insufficient or unavailable for any reason, then the Township shall have a lien for the total amount of such costs incurred by the Township the amount of which may be placed upon the delinquent tax roll relative to all lots, units and parcels within the development, on a pro rata basis, to accrue interest and penalties, and to be treated and collected as and in the manner provided by law for the collection of delinquent real property taxes. 
11.  Grant the Township the right to enter onto the property and to inspect any part of the community wastewater utility system for compliance with this chapter, the development agreement and all applicable laws. 
12.  Consent to personal jurisdiction and venue in the county circuit court, agree that money damages are not an adequate remedy at law and cannot make the Township whole for damages arising out of the breach of the development agreement, and agree to injunctive remedies in any action brought by the Township to enforce the development agreement or enforce compliance with applicable ordinances and laws. 
13.  Contain a provision mandating that, in the event the Livingston County Road Commission requires the use of any of the right-of-way used by facilities that are a part of the CWUS, the facilities shall be moved as requested by the Livingston County Road Commission at the sole cost and expense of the CWUS. 
14.  Include any other provisions related to the proposed system and deemed necessary by the Township. 
15.  The provisions of the development agreement shall also be included in a separate document, in a form approved by the Township attorney, shall be recorded against the applicable properties, and included within the development documents that run with the land and in disclosure documents delivered to prospective purchasers prior to the execution of a purchase agreement for property proposed to be serviced by a community wastewater utility system. 
(7)  A permanent and irrevocable easement, in recordable form, shall be signed by the CWUS owner and any other necessary property owners granting the Township and its employees, agents, and assigns access to and the right to enter on the development and all property upon which the system is located for the purpose of inspections and any and all other activities permitted under this chapter and the development agreement. The property on which the system is located shall be maintained so it is accessible at all times, prohibiting any structures or landscaping within such area that would unreasonably interfere with such access. 
(8)  The community wastewater utility system shall be a general common element of a condominium in which it is located, or part of common areas of any other development. The system shall be inspected, monitored, operated, maintained, repaired and replaced by the CWUS owner with the right of the CWUS owner to assess the owners for all such costs. 
(9)  The CWUS owner shall establish and at all times maintain an adequate operating and maintenance reserve sufficient for five years of monitoring, inspection, operation, maintenance and repair of the system, and an adequate equipment replacement reserve sufficient to fund replacement of the CWUS and equipment after the end of its anticipated useful life. The amounts for these reserves shall be provided by the system design engineer and shall be subject to the review and approval of the Township engineer. The development documents shall provide user fees and assessments of owners to ensure perpetual funding of the reserves at the designated level, including reasonable increases to account for inflation and other factors. The reserve funds shall be established and held under an escrow agreement, which shall be submitted to the Township for review and approval prior to issuance of the CWUS permit. The Township may require escrowed reserve funds over and above those required by other applicable agencies should the Township find that escrows required by other agencies are insufficient to cover obligations. In the event of non-performance by the CWUS owner or the CWUS operator of proper maintenance and operation of the CWUS, the association or the owners shall have the right and obligation to thaw on such escrow reserve fund for the purpose of undertaking proper maintenance, inspection, operation and replacement of the CWTJS, and payment of fees, costs and expenses of same. 
(10)  A copy of the articles of incorporation and bylaws of the association and a copy of the form of the restrictive covenant/deed restrictions/or master deed imposing upon owners the obligation to pay for all capital and operating costs and reserves associated with the community wastewater utility systems. 
(11)  Evidence satisfactory to the Township board that the CWUS operator employs one or more individuals who have all qualifications and certifications required under applicable laws to operate the system. 
(d)  No building permit shall be issued for any structure or development proposed to be serviced by a community sewer system until the Township Board has approved such system in accordance with the terms and provision of this chapter and until the system complies with all otherwise applicable laws and ordinances. 
(e)  Anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, the Township shall not be responsible or obligated to perform any needed or desired operation, monitoring, inspection, repairs, maintenance, improvement, and/or replacement of the system or any portion thereof. 
(f)  The CWUS operator and/or CWUS owner shall furnish periodic operating and maintenance reports to the Township building department and department of public works in accordance with the maintenance requirements and schedule. Any such requirements shall be made a part of the development documents. 
(g)  After the Township's approval, the development documents referenced in section 34-421(e) and development agreement referenced in section 34-421(e) shall be recorded at the office of the county register of deeds. After approval by the Township, the development documents, as they pertain to the system, shall not be changed without the written consent and approval of the Township. The documents shall display language to that effect. 
(h)  The CWUS owner, association, owners and/or users of the system shall be jointly and severally responsible for all costs involved in the installation, operation, monitoring, inspection, maintenance, repair, replacement and liability associated with the system. The Township may, at its option, elect to collect all costs it may incur in connection with the system pursuant to this article, or by direct court action against the CWUS owner, CWUS operator, association, owners, and/or users of the system.
